This paper discuss experimental observation thermodynamic state variables thermal decomposition evolution thermal explosion energetic materials. We discuss continuous measurement observables across time scales bridging pre-ignition thermal decomposition regime postignition burn propagation regimes. Techniques measuring temperature density pressure continuously discussed results presented thermal explosions HMX based formulation PBX-9501. Comparisons observables rates change discussed. These observations used offer definition ignition distinguishes slow processes thermal decomposition heating switch fast consumption solid internal burning. The response energetic materials temperature occurs time scales ranging microseconds hours. This represents dynamic range nearly 10 orders magnitude time making energetic materials extremely challenging study experimentally computationally. Experimentally following observables microsecond resolution durations hours typically possible. Current treatments cleave problem regimes slow pre-ignition regime lasting hours evolving time scale seconds fast post-ignition regime lasting hundreds microseconds order microseconds. Computationally change time scales treated handing problem preignition models post-ignition burn propagation models typically pressure dependent programmed burn. While considering response different time regimes evolve different rates logical approach material actually evolves continuously pre post ignition regimes. We attempted provide sufficient heating rates accelerate decomposition generate thermal explosion. The onset thermal explosion often called ignition. Although word ignition used distinguishing behavior pre- post- ignition difficult exact meaning ignition well agreed upon likely depends observables used discussed sections below. Post-ignition burn propagation occur via either slow conductive propagation solid faster convective propagation gas phase. propagation occurs time scale tens microseconds. A subsequent even faster regime detonation possible confinement conditions path lengths sufficient deflagration detonation trasnsition DDT present. That regime currently outside scope work. Due change time scales microseconds hours covering multiple regimes hard follow single observable entire event. Our work focused developing diagnostics monitored hours time resolution microseconds. Parker WX-6 Explosive Applications Special Projects Los Alamos National Laboratory Inadvertent initiation high explosives HE impact-friction event major safety concern among explosives community. To better understand frictional heating process event one two dimensional thermal kinetic time-to-ignition models developed using commercially available nite element modeling package COMSOL. This modeling work coincided drop-skid experiments conducted Los Alamos National Laboratory supported experiments. These models include well-developed four-step Arrhenius model PBX 9501 previously shown good agreement friction impact studies various grit-inclusion radii simulate typical grit sizes concern 10 1000m. The one dimensional model followed assumption temperature bounding melting points commonly available grit surface materials plastics aluminum steel silica. In model boundary condition forced near melting point given material. Thermal gradients allowed relax ignition time noted. A total 50 simulation runs completed order encompass chosen parameter space. While model provided good agreement previous work became obvious unable predict behavior observed coincident drop-skid To better simulate behavior complex two dimensional model developed. This model captured frictional heating single grit particle silica various surfaces interest. In model several assumptions made including total conversion drop velocity sliding velocity mechanical deformation material involved constant coefcient kinetic friction. Appleby-Thomas Cranfield University Shrivenham Swindon SN6 8LA UK AWE Aldermaston Reading RG7 4PR UK Abstract. A novel ceramic ramp loading system developed compatible gas gun plate impact magnetic particle velocity gauge techniques. The use graded areal density loading technique involving rapid prototyped ceramic enables wide parameter space efficiently explored. Ramp loadings varying duration produced Kel-F 81 polymer hydrocode modelling system successful replicating key features. Initial experiments pressed HMX based explosive EDC 37 shown evidence ramp loadingfinite compression rates desensitising effect explosives run detonation response comparison thin sustained shock pulses similar input particle velocity. This paper building previous study1 development ramp loading technique used impart controlled ramp loading paths inert energetic targets. The aim body work develop methodology used study effects ramp loading run detonation explosive Experimental constraints dictated technique used compatible gas gun plate impact2 embedded particle velocity PV gauge techniques34. This meant several approaches previously reported literature using metallic materials56 unable employed7. Therefore novel method developed based technique devised Winter et al.8 using flyer graded areal density. The main development whereas Winter used metal flyers variant uses flyers comprised rapid prototyped alumina ceramic. The primary diagnostic used work version embedded particle velocity gauge based upon developed LANL.349. This elegant technique uses gauge package consisting multiple metallic elements conjunction known flat magnetic field. Careful metrology induction enable particle velocity experienced gauge elements calculated assumed gauge elements move surrounding material significantly disrupt 1-D flow combined Faradays heterogeneous explosives desensitised ramp loadings relative sustained pulses. This observed pressed HMX based explosive PBX-94041011 Setchell. Experimental constraints dictated ramp loading method selected use nonconductive materials requirement also imposed velocity capabilities gas guns available. This meant alumina ceramic selected producing solid flyers density gradient instance Spark Plasma Sintering12. protracted development route given limited inhouse capabilities area. Other techniques use reverse-elastic moduli materials e.g. fuzed silica 13 offered limited parameter space adjusting ramp variables therefore graded areal density method selected. The gradient duration ramp loading controlled alteration spike buffer parameters. Flyers produced using industrial stereolithography study thus enabling rapid progression theoretical design experimental results. approach The graded areal density system comprises system consisting flyer plate matching buffer plate. The flyer plate graded areal density i.e. surface consisting multiple raised structures. The technique used uses spikes comprised square pyramids. This shape chosen enables high packing density structures formed although geometries conical structures feasible. The buffer plate made similar material placed contact front face target. The flyer launched target per standard gas gun plate impact technique. Upon impact spikes form multiple wavelets constructively interfere enters target. The target undergoes complex loading path best described ramp loading comprises features shockless compression A schematic system used shown Fig. 1 example parameters given typical experimental setup. For characterization thermal sensitivity explosives different types tests developed past. In cookoff tests explosive sample slowly heated critical explosive determined. Scientific Background When referring thermal mode laser initiation-as opposed shock initiation using intense laser pulses678 build upon extensive literature classic thermal ignition also work laser ignition. A thermally initiated reaction explosive also called cookoff divided preignition represents phase ignition explosive material. Here ignition defined point time reaction becomes selfsustaining. In postignition regime strength violence reaction interest. In literature different techniques used approximations made model two cookoff regimes. The preignition phase mostly approximated thermal-chemical coupled problem example Zinn Mader10. The chemical models trying match results one-dimensional time explosion ODTX test11 became sophisticated using multi-step kinetics.12 compared ODTX results paper. Mechanical forces yet considered. Comparably Boley Rubenchik5 numerically solved heat equation including Arrhenius source term simulate pulsed laser initiation confined explosives thus neglecting mechanical effects also limited preignition phase. Rubenchik13 modelled cw laser localized heat source analytically approximated critical temperatures steady state well unsteady state laser initiation. Ali et al.3 analytically modelled time laser ignition unconfined explosives based laser irradiance using dual criteria ignition model. Nevertheless significance mechanical effects preignition regime already noticed Zinn Rogers14 used rupture confinement external quantity calculating time explosion even completion reaction. Hobbs et al.15 included mechanical domain preignition simulation coupling thermal-chemical mechanical code thereby reproducing ODTX times explosion pressure failure confinement. They concluded mechanics must considered cookoff analysis.15 Very recently Hobbs Kaneshige16 published pressure-dependent preignition model TATB-based insensitive high explosive PBX 9502 reproduces decreasing reaction rate due gas release venting SITI tests. In simulations energy equation integrated pressure calculated using appended auxiliary equations. The model also validated bucket17 tests. SITI bucket tests apply pressure transducers done work omit investigate effect venting. The authors found reaction rate pressure-dependent TNT18 PETN19. Additional experimental evidence possibly pressure-dependent reaction rates indicated number papers Shaw et al.20 demonstrated experiments decreasing ignition times temperatures increasing static pressure energetic materials nitromethane. Similarly stmark Grns3 found critical laser ignition energy decreasing increasing ambient gas pressure 100 bar Composition B amongst others. However Henson et al.21 argued static high dynamic selfpressurization determining rate constants. Kaneshige et al.2 observed pressure increase slowing beginning thermal runaway SITI tests HMX-based PBX 9501 associated point time completion gas generating process. equivalent Chidester et al.22 performed comprehensive study cookoff violence thus also examined postignition behavior. With instrumented largescale thermalchemical preignition hydrodynamic-reactive ignition growth postignition simulations showed slow heating violent fast heating fragment velocities thermal explosions fast intentional detonations. Likewise analyzing Los Alamos Radial Cookoff tests23 Asay et al. 24 stated fast cookoff usually less violent slow cookoff reaction starts surface probe instead center. These observations lay foundations interpreting results laser initiation tests intense laser irradiation causes rather fast heating. Compared successive simulations made Chidester et al.22 different modeling strategy applied Yoh et al.25. In single thermalchemical-mechanical hydrocode simulation common pressuremade independent multi-step preignition pressure-dependent burn front model based Vieilles including failure confinement. The literature pressure dependency thermal ignition agrees upon fact final fast reaction mostly occurs gas phase amount gas held together sustained reaction. External confinement case self-confinement high ambient pressure thus facilitate ignition. Summary Conclusions An experimental setup quantitative measurement pressure temperature confined explosive samples laser irradiation developed. Experimental data obtained two explosives Composition B Seismoplast different laser powers 1 kW 5 kW presented. The measured ignition times follow clear trend function laser intensity similar explosives. The temperature interface shell explosive parameter evaluation experiments since represents maximum temperature explosive material. The initial rate temperature increase measured position good agreement FEM simulations solving heat conduction equation sample. After time faster temperature increase observed experiments may explained onset reaction thus significant amount heat production explosive material. For measured ignition temperatures relatively large fluctuations results different experiments observed indicating position tip thermocouple might moving stage interaction. A modified sample setup currently prepared stable positioning thermocouple future experiments. In addition pressure build-up inside sample could measured piezo-electric pressure transducers. In experiments pressure initially remains close zero continuously increases specific delay specific rise time point ignition. This observation qualitative agreement model calculations presented paper. Typical time scales measured pressure rise time order milliseconds Composition B seconds Seismoplast. The reason difference yet understood subject future experiments modified setup pressure gauge. experimental observation requires numerical simulation thermo-mechanical reaction irradiated sample. As first approach carried simulations take account energy absorption laser calculate heat conduction multi-phase sample. For comprehensive simulation kinetics explosive material end set computational material model calculates thermo-mechanical response material based Arrhenius model reaction kinetics mixing rule explosive material reaction products. The implementation reactive material model hydrocode simulation currently progress. The final goal work benchmark numerical models experimental results develop capability predicting response explosives laser irradiation. Abstract. To explore potential hazard posed multiple fragment strikes developed capability launch 2 fragments gun 30mm powder gun range velocities achieve impacts acceptor charge good control spatial temporal separation strikes. Typically work date used 12.7mm diameter steel spheres ball bearings projectiles concentrated achieving spatial separation 20-30mm temporal separation ca. 100-200s. We used dual launch system conduct firings explosive filled test charges. Results tests clearly indicated potential detonation upon second strike velocities well needed shock initiation single fragment. In paper describe experimental techniques used results obtained discuss likely mechanisms controlling target response. Fragment impact pose significant hazard many weapons systems warheads rocket motors. Fragments come wide range shapes sizes velocities case nearby detonation multiple strikes highly likely. Currently vulnerability fragment impact normally assessed according STANAG 4496. This testing regime employs single 14.3mm diameter 160 degree conical tipped steel projectile either 1830ms 2530ms depending upon perceived threat scenarios. Testing consider potential threat multiple fragment strikes sometimes carried using FRAGMAT test projects steel cubes target using explosive donor. This test difficult conduct due random nature strikes particularly suitable fundamental study mechanisms governing target response. It considered initial fragment strike strikes could sensitise weapon system subsequent impacts may lead violent reaction would predicted based single fragment studies. In particular seemed likely possibility detonation via XDT X unknown Detonation Transition DDT Deflagration Detonation Transition process may well increased multiple opposed single impact. Consequently explore potential hazard developed dual fragment launch capability used system conduct firings explosive filled following section describe experimental techniques used achieve dual fragment launch observe acceptor charge We developed dual fragment launch capability based upon 30mm powder gun. To date concentrated launching 12.7mm diameter steel spherical fragments housed Tufnol sabots. The two sabotsfragments loaded gun barrel one immediately behind other. The sabot employed rear fragment differs front sabot groove machined along length outer surface. This groove allows propellant gases accelerate first sabotfragment slightly ahead second one. By changing dimensions groove different temporal separations fragment arrival achieved. The projectile also slightly offset rear sabot provide spatial separation strikes. Investigating Colliding Shock Wave Detonation Wave Interactions Influence Catherine E Johnson Joshua M Hoffman Braden T Lusk Neal Lee Department Mining Engineering University Kentucky Lexington KY 40506 Nelson Brothers LLC 888 Oakwood Road Charleston WV 25314 Abstract. The practice dual initiation using precise timing electronic detonators boreholes thought beneficial increasing fragmentation desired location rock strata. When shock wave process begins. This shock wave starts velocity detonation explosive decreases quite rapidly enters rock short distance reduced sonic velocity particular rock. At areas surrounding blast column radial cracks form small delay. The formation cracks due interaction number waves propagating arresting re-mobilizing upon collision another wave free face. The outgoing shockwave travels cracks radially creating tangential stress. This pressure compressive since rock weaker tension trailing portion wave reflections typically cause rock break. When stress reaches free face reflects back due change density tensile wave causing breakage4. When two waves collide free face present rarefaction waves meet magnitude forming cracks. At AWE HERMES implemented material model Lagrangian LS-DYNA Finite Element FE code8. The HERMES model comprises several sub models including constitutive model strength porosity surface area fragmentation ignition model ignition front propagation model model burning ignition. The dual criterion ignition incorporates stress history plastic strain rate duration time von-Mises stress effective plastic strain rate 1t time plastic work begins deposited local explosive 2t time ignition occurs specific plastic power specific plastic energy integral specific power curve shown shadow areas Fig.3. 0W threshold parameters ignition criterion. Advanced Engineering Analysis Explosive Applications Special Projects Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos New Mexico 87545 Engineering Sciences Center Energetic Components Realization Sandia National Laboratories Albuquerque New Mexico 87105 Abstract. Cookoff plastic bonded explosive PBX9502 strong pressure effects exposure abnormal thermal environments. A decomposition model PBX 9502 recently developed1 include effects pressure density confinement. The purpose current work evaluate predictive ability thermal decomposition model using Latin Hypercube Sampling LHS techniques. The LHS predictions compared Lawrence Livermore National Laboratories LLNL one-dimensional time-to-explosion ODTX experiments Sandia National Laboratories SNL instrumented thermal ignition experiments SITI Los Alamos National Laboratories LANL intermediatescale cookoff bucket ISCB experiments. All experimental data lies within LHS prediction limits. The objective assess predictive capabilities model using LHS techniques thermal ignition experiments use PBX 9502 mass quantities Fig. 1 range 1.8 1312 g. The final reaction direct decomposition TATB form equilibrium products. The four-step mechanism reads1 1. H2Oa H2Og 2. TATB MF H2Om 3. MF 6.52 gasm 4.18 carbonm 4. TATB 7.5 gast 3.9 carbont subscript means adsorbed subscript g means gaseous subscript means coming mono-furazan decomposition subscript means coming TATB decomposition. The PBX 9502 decomposition model pressure dependent rate TATB decomposition assumed proportional PPo0.7. Pressure calculated BKWS equation state. The model sensitive available gas volume. If PBX 9502 pressed high densities decomposition gases readily leave explosive. Rather decomposition takes place interior explosive called closed-pore decomposition. If material damaged gases leave PBX overall pressure lower reaction rates lower. The PBX 9502 model several options calculate gas pressure. These options based available gas volume system interest. For example PBX damaged decomposition gases leave PBX accumulate confining apparatus. If confining apparatus open atmosphere gases leave system rates lower. If PBX damaged pressed densities near theoretical maximum density TMD gases stay within closed pore network pressure increases. The higher decomposition causes ignition times short since reaction rates higher. Discussion results In current work used pressure dependent thermal decomposition model predict thermal response eventual cookoff PBX 9502. We simulated response ODTX experiment 2 g SITI experiment 22 g ISCB test 1300 g. The model parameters originally obtained SITI experiments. The ODTX ISCB experiments considered validation experiments since used obtain model parameters. The ODTX experiment confined vented although suspect plastic bonded explosive may self-sealed elevated temperatures. We recommend additional ODTX experiments better venting pressure measurements. We believe model predictions effect density 98 TMD sealed ODTX tests 85 TMD vented experiments predicted adequately. The model fit high-density confined SITI experiments well low-density vented SITI experiments. The model option predicting bulk volume changes expansion well decomposition gas induced swelling. The swelling model added model fit SITI data. Additional experiments needed improve swelling model accurate predictions. A Mesh-free DSD Front Tracker Arbitrary HE Boundary Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Livermore California U.S.A Abstract. A new mesh-free DSD front tracker explicitly solves detonation front propagation implemented arbitrarily specified HE boundary. Compared previously existing mesh-based DSD implementations new method advantages reduced cost improved accuracy minimized data space enhanced capabilities. The new DSD front tracker puts marked particles HE front tracks motion particles front normal direction governed time-dependent ODE system. The difficulty associated implicit DSD boundary treatment much reduced explicit methodology arbitrarily specified HE boundary geometry. The issue associated change front topology resolved efficient local inclusion test. Particles redistributed front maintain desired resolution. This DSD front tracker validated comparisons exact reactive flow solutions rate-stick problems. In addition shown capable dead-zone simulation. Programmed HE burn detonation shock dynamics DSD model efficient method lighting time calculation compared reactive flow modeling requires high resolution reaction zone. Existing DSD implementations solve level-set PDE equivalent PDE mesh apply angle condition HEinert boundary. Among existing DSD algorithms finite-difference method easily performed Cartesian mesh. However treatment becomes complicated detonation front HE boundary implicitly defined 1 2. With renormalization distance field narrowband methodology reduce cost would converge true solution even relatively trivial concave geometry 3. Another method using least-squared fitting lighting front existing hydro mesh also implemented narrowband fashion boundary condition still difficult apply even HE boundary explicitly specified body-fitting mesh 4. Because mesh resolution cannot adjusted local high curvature regions cannot resolved mesh-based DSD method. In addition meshbased method requires relatively big storage space. To reduce difficulties mentioned DSD algorithm detonation front HE boundary explicitly expressed becomes desirable. Such method may provide easier boundary treatment adjustable local resolution accurate efficient solution smaller data space. Recently implemented mesh-free DSD arbitrarily specified HE boundary. The new detonation front according tracks particles distributed tracker called SDOT curvature law curved fitting neighbor particle positions express local front geometry. The DSD boundary angle condition used explicitly derive position boundary particle. The challenge topology change treated dropping lit run boundary particles reassigning neighbors particles lost neighbors. A redistribution particles performed condition based distance curvature maintain front quality. With new algorithm need solve governing nonlinear PDE previous implemented DSD methods. Instead set timedependent ODEs derived DSD evolution equation 5 solved advancing detonation front. This PDE ODE conversion third order accurate space introduces error time. In article describe mathematical aspects numerical techniques front motion topology change boundary treatment surface management associated mesh-less DSD front tracker. Some 2D numerical examples verify validate new method follow. HE Boundary Presentation Fixed Control Points Define Boundary Faces In practice boundary geometry usually specified set control points rule connect define boundary faces. For example rate-stick geometry described four control points define four faces. To define boundary two-dimensions control points ordered counter-clock-wise pair two consecutive points defining boundary face. A face planar curved depending whether continuity slope control point consideration. In axisymmetrical geometry faces faces two-dimensions revolved around axis. Rather complicated boundary geometry may defined small set control points seen numerical examples article. The smallness boundary data usually true threedimensions well. Burn Front Representation Particles Distance-based Neighbor Relationship A detonation front time step presented particles distributed front fig. 1. To completely describe given detonation front sufficient associate particle unit normal vector. The local geometry front particle defined neighbors. We select neighbors based distance particles. We specify search-length may desired resolution problem. At given time step particle looks particles within distance neighbors. At next time-step neighbor particles may move neighborhood given particle. This dealt locally old neighbor relations. Each particle assigned unit normal vector direction motion. Our choice fit plane 3D line 2D local particle positions find normal adjust later curved-fitting. The orientation normal determined specifying order neighbor particles. In 2D particle carries left right neighbor define orientation. In 3D neighbor particles ordered counter-clock-wise projections fitting plane. Fig.1. Particle presentation local detonation front 3D shown. Vectors normal direction propagation detonation. Front Motion PDE ODE Conversion Equation Motion Detonation A given particle P detonation front moves normal direction velocity Dn subscript n normal computed given Dn- relation. The front curvature obtained fitting curved surface neighbor particle positions surface normal coordinate defined To leading order approximation DSD theory predicts Dn detonation velocity normal direction function front curvature i.e. Dn Dn. The motion front described partial differential equation Fig.2. The local front normal coordinate given particle P. The front geometry defined quadratic fitting neighbor particles filled circles within distance P. Unfilled circles mark particles neighbors P. In equation surface defines position front space time. The proposed method solve level-sets merely tracks geometry front time. The normal vector particle P front dimensions local Cartesian-coordinate system defined setting origin P normal n-axis -axis axis principal tangential unit vectors fitting. In intrinsic normal coordinate front geometry generally expressed n h neighborhood P. Here assume surface represents detonation front sufficiently smooth define curvature. Such surface may take form Taylor expansion third order spatial accuracy format Where coefficients b c e f considered functions time carrying change geometry detonation front. To order care local geometry would symmetry n-axis coordinate A reduced form front expansion eq. 2 surface normal coordinate derived. Let us consider time T0. Without loss generality T0 set 0. Local Linear Stability Time-steps For near CJ diverging detonation wave curvature positive detonation speed CJ value. In case linear stability analysis ODE system shows negative growth factors. The time integration stable. For converging detonation take CJ velocity propagate detonation uncontrolled growth introduced choice. Rearranging particles tends smooth front would also help stabilize numerical scheme. However time step limited order avoid unnecessary reordering neighbor particles. For purpose testing taken constant time steps. We performed global linear stability analysis new tracking algorithm. However believe stability condition derived 1 sensible choice limiting time steps. Treatment Topology Change Inclusion Test Utilizing Cartesian Virtual Grid The information marked particle moved boundary burned region provided inclusion test. Directly applying conventional inclusion tests case many points inefficient. We implemented inclusion test based locality improve We choose length-unit lc scale inclusion problem. After dividing coordinates lc particle contained unit cube i1 j j1 k k1 j k integer floor values coordinates particle position. The virtual-cubes contain HE boundary identified finding intersections unit cubes boundary fig. 3. We implemented directional-walking intersection algorithm6 boundaries consists planar Hermite cubic spline faces. We perform local quadratic fit detonation front compute intersection unit cubes. When particle located cube sliced either HE boundary detonation front check relative position boundary front particles contained local inclusion test inside unit cube only. This approach makes inclusion test efficient. The size virtual cube lc fraction volume HE region divided surface boundary cubes cubes crossed boundary need tested inclusion boundary faces cross cube contains given particle. These virtual cubes used later local neighbor search help interpolation lighting times. Because virtual cubes crossed boundary front need stored given time-step data storage virtual cubes also small. Fig. 3. Utilizing background virtual cubes particles contained boundary cubes need test inclusion boundary faces crossing cube contains given particle. Each virtual cube unit one scaling lc. We choice handle frontfront frontboundary interactions exact geometrical intersection. New particles put intersection define front interaction sharpness. The resulting high accuracy another advantage compared mesh-based PDE-solving DSD algorithm would able capture sharp front-features. Boundary Treatment Explicitly Applying DSD Boundary-Angle Condition For boundary particle two-dimensions two nearest inner neighbor particles used construct circle intersects boundary DSD wall-angle c. The boundary particle put intersection fig. 4. In three-dimensions idea similar fit boundary particle quadratic surface updated positions interior neighbors angle constraint applied intersection front boundary. The associated algebra hard perform planar boundary geometry. For curved boundary solution bit harder handle local planar fitting boundary done approximate solution. A finer solution would require iterations. Fig. 4. A circle passes interior neighbors A B intersects boundary DSD angle c constructed locate boundary particle C. In three-dimensions DSD angular boundary condition applied plane perpendicular boundary contains front normal vector. New particles put intersections. As result solution naturally keeps sharpness. The procedure described iterated entire HE region lit. A Small Data Space Reduced Complexity In practice ignorable storage needed specifying boundary geometry. Furthermore time step information needed advance front carried positions particles current front. Compared mesh-based DSD method spatial complexity reduced dimension. Furthermore proposed method third-order accuracy space thus high resolution necessary unless local high front curvature needs resolved. Since spatial complexity reduced minimal data space required store boundary geometry current particle positions virtual cubes crossed front boundary advance detonation front. Parallelization possibly needed even rather big problem. Supply Lighting Times Local Interpolations The marked particles distributed front time-step i.e. time contours provides table lighting times. Numerical Examples Arbitrary Boundaries Example A Curved Geometry As show fig. 7 boundary HE region shape star-fish. With mesh based DSD calculation many nodes would needed present curved boundary. This procedure repeats fronts become smaller preset tolerance. Example C Simple Dead-Zone Simulation The DSD theory predicts detonation front curvature exceeds critical value detonation speed arrives failure value corresponding detonation propagate. In corner-turning test high curvature cusp appears corner dead zone defined trace cusp. The cusp moves normal direction failure velocity continuity speed. Validation Mesh-less DSD Tracker We first verified implementation new method rate-stick geometry exact DSD solution linear Dn- relation. Let width stick 2R taking DCJ velocity unit Dn 1 R length unit scale system c 4 system first integral case 2D planar geometry Where term T 1 C212 C steady travelling velocity. With taken 0.1 obtain C 0.969723 accurately recovered 6 digits mesh-less detonation front tracker. We also compared numerical results obtained particle tracker reactive flow simulation CHEETAH rate-stick problems LX-17. We numerically derive front velocity curvature relation CHEETAH data. Then input derived numerical Dn- relation run DSD front tracker. An almost exact match front shapes particle tracking DNS obtained. We consider result justification LX-17 DSD study mesh-free front tracking algorithm. The Numerical Dn- Relationship LX-17 We employ CHEETAH generated steady LX-17 detonation rate-stick geometry represented data-points front. We evenly divide radius intervals. At joint intervals search-distance used look data-points within distance . The selected data-points used fit quadratic curve obtain curvature. The slope fitting curve provides information normal front velocity joint. Then obtain Dn pair joint point Dn- curve LX-17 ratestick. An extrapolation derived Dn- curve small curvature gives DCJ 7.73 cmms agreement experimental results 9. Fig.10. A steady detonation front 50 mm ratestick test generated mesh-less DSD tracker dashed curve using numerical Dn- derived LX-17 overlaps front obtained DNS CHEETAH model solid Comparison CHEETAH Rate-stick Fronts We run mesh-less DSD front checker numerical Dn- relation derived LX-17 boundary angle 0.4472 . The tracker generated front visually overlaps CHEETAH front. This shows mesh-free DSD tracking adequately predict detonation arriving time. The proposed particle DSD front tracker admits arbitrarily specified boundary geometry. The usual intrinsic numerical difficulties associated moving particle front tracker7 resolved basic geometrical operations. The particles present detonation front rearranged times avoid non-ideal distributions. Particles easily added removed front maintain quality front geometry. The issue particles moving invalid region addressed efficient inclusioninteraction test. Furthermore sharp solution multi-front interaction obtained kept particle tracker utilizing exact geometrical intersections. Besides fast accurate new DSD front tracker advantage compact. At given time boundary geometry front geometry necessary carry calculation. This tracker high spatial accuracy third order thus high resolution usually required. A local high front curvature also resolved existing DSD methods difficulties resolving high local curvature. The lighting time hydro mesh obtained local implementation particle data even direct measurement front run time. This method validated comparisons numerical simulation detailed reaction chemistry model various DSD parameters. We conclude DSD tracker capable serve efficient light weight tool programmed burn detonation shock dynamics DSD. Phoenix AZ contract U.S. Army Research Laboratory APG MD 21005 Abstract. Campbell Travis 8th IDS reported results intriguing experiment initiated detonation top edge super-critical slab explosive immersed water. This detonation collided head-on weak shock wave originating bottom end slab. Detonation continued propagating material altered weak shock abruptly extinguished. The quenching mechanism debated ever since. Twenty years prior Liddiard 4th IDS reported results waterfilled aquarium containing spherical donor charge surrounded thin cylindrical explosive samples positioned various radii adjust shock input pressure. Images high-speed camera allowed determination threshold-for-burning function pressure. In Ref. Liddiard provides time interval shock impingement onset combustion. The current work found time interval function pressure forms lower bound early time Pop Plot data implying combustion event continues operate time scale transition detonation. A possible quenching mechanism occurs running detonation encounters shocked material exceeded threshold combustion. Based concept analysis wave interaction developed timing dictated solely Liddiards data predicted run-length detonation collides 1.33 GPa shock wave close Campbells observation PBX9404 1.84 gcc. Desensitization solid composite explosives observed many investigators1-6 mostly standpoint precursor shock wave making difficult shock-initiate explosive. A commonly accepted explanation based concept748-11 dead pressing accompanied pressure range. Precursor shock waves pressure amplitude lower limit weak alter explosive material retains shock sensitivity. Pressure amplitudes upper limit promptly However shock waves pressure amplitude within given range capable collapsing poresvoids reduces population available hot-spots. However hotspot formation continued combustion ratedependent process competing transient heat loss determine failure success initiation. Possibly crucial factor controlling outcome dead explosive reacting material profile shapeduration precursor shock wave. A detonation propagating material super-critical geometry normally difficult stop. Some exceptions involve strong divergence wave corner turning12. At 8th IDS Campbell Travis4 reported results insightful intriguing experiment see Fig. 1 initiated detonation top edge super-critical slab explosive PBX-9404 COMPB-3 immersed water. This detonation collided head-on weak shock wave originating bottom end slab. Following collision detonation continued propagating material altered weak shock -- abruptly extinguished. The current investigation proposes mechanism quench detonation based solely Liddiards data time-to-combustion. Once detonation collides opposing weak-level shock wave propagation continues compressed explosive encounters onset combustion -- detonation fails. Yarrington Engineering Sciences Center Sandia National Laboratories Albuquerque NM 87185 Integrated Military Systems Sandia National Laboratories Albuquerque NM 87185 Abstract. The Jacobs-Cowperthwaite-Zwisler-Sandia JCZS database1 used 15 years JCZ32 equation state EOS calculate detonation properties product shock Hugoniots variety explosives. The scope JCZS database increased including species ions currently used National Aeronautics Space Administration NASA Lewis Research Centers computer program CEA3 Chemical Equilibrium Applications. CEA uses ideal gas EOS opposed real gas EOS valid high pressure andor densities JCZ3-EOS uses intermolecular potentials. We also included piecewise fits specific heat capacities Cp insure reasonable extrapolations temperatures high 20000 K. The new library piecewise Cp fits exponential 6 parameters implemented CTH-TIGER equilibrium code. The CTH-TIGER code chemical equilibrium solver45 coupled shock physics code CTH. Background History ideal gas EOS since temperatures high pressures low detonation products far enough apart However condensed-phase explosives produce higher pressures require EOS accounts intermolecular attraction repulsion Figure 1 shows brief history thermochemical codes equations state used calculate detonation properties condensed explosives laboratory. In 1950s Lawrence Radiation Laboratory Livermore California used RUBY code calculate detonation properties. The Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory LASL used BKW program similar calculations. Both RUBY BKW6 codes complex EOS mixed intimately thermodynamic hydrodynamic calculations within code. In 1960s Stanford Research Institute SRI developed TIGER code45 goal simplify detonation calculations using modular subroutines thermodynamics EOS. In 1970s Cowperthwaite Zwisler5 put JCZ EOS TIGER giving code EOS options ideal BKW JCZ. Only 12 gases consisting carbon C hydrogen H oxygen O nitrogen N aluminum Al JCZ parameters. aLawrence Radiation Laboratory LRL bLos Alamos Scientific Laboratory LASL cStanford Research Institute SRI dSandia National Laboratories SNL eLawrence Livermore National Laboratory LLNL Fig. 1. Brief history SNLs EOS work17 based SRIs original TIGER code.45 The original TIGER code4 could consider 30 gas species 10 condensed products composed 10 elements although code typically used reactants containing C H N O Al. In 1990s restrictions eliminated Hobbs et al. created BKWS7 JCZS1 EOS databases considered 56 elements 747 gases 401 condensed products. BKW parameters exponential-6 intermolecular potential determined gases. In 1994 Fried8 converted laboratories version TIGER BKWS database computer language C added graphical user interface GUI. Fried et al.9 also created BKW parameterization called BKWC database limited scope since lacked important species dissociated hydrogen H. Fried et al.10 created useful EOS database referred EXP6 EOS. The EXP6 database contains many potential parameters JCZS database accurate JCZS database calculating detonation properties.10 Problems JCZS database occur temperature exceeds 6000 K. The specific heats JCZS databases fit polynomials using data JANAF tables11 typically good 6000 K gases 1500 K condensed products. The condensed Cps extrapolated 6000 K monotonically increasing polynomial. Above 6000 K Cp extrapolations good sometimes decrease temperature even going negative shown Fig. 2 C CO CO2. The Cp fits gases used NASA-CEA3 code also Fig. 2. Cp fits JCZS JCZS2i databases. Temperatures shocks easily exceed 10000 K. For example air shock produced Equation 3 solved substituting specific heats 1 2 3. The integration constants obtained assuming enthalpy entropy reference temperature 298.15 K equal heat entropy formation respectively. The dimensionless dimensionless entropy enthalpy RT h RT S R . insure extrapolations reasonable without problems negative heat capacities shown Fig. 2. JCZS2i specific heats extrapolated high temperatures linearly using specific heat highest known temperature following value dimensionless specific heat 106 K depending number atoms N All Cp fits plotted 20000 K Miller et al.12 insure reasonable extrapolations. The molar volume ice liquid water 1 atm using Eq. 5 shown Fig. 3.a data.13 Figures 3.b-f show calculated measured11 specific heat water shock Hugoniot data1415 universal liquid Hugoniot16 water sound speed data17 pressure dependent melting point solid water data13 open-air detonation Comp-B exceed 10000 K. To simulate phenomena using shock physics code CTH coupled version TIGER code CTH. The coupled code referred CTH-TIGER. The primary objective current work describe new EOS library called JCZS2i database. The database acronym retains JCZS reference 1 2 refers version 2 database refers ions database. This database EOS parameters BKW covolumes JCZ potential parameters. monoatomic diatomic The new database uses piecewise specific heat fits NASA-CEC code3 polyatomic specific heat fits accurate 20000 K. The One Dimensional Time Explosion ODTX system Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory used since 1970s measure times explosion threshold thermal explosion temperature determine kinetic parameters energetic materials. The ODTX testing also provide useful data assessing thermal explosion violence energetic materials. It useful tool characterization newly developed energetic formulations. Recent ODTX experimental data well data modeling ANPZ DMDNP reported paper. More diagnostics added system enhance capability. Some energetic materials e.g. hydrogen peroxidefuel mixtures1 may explode cook-off fairly low temperatures violence thermal explosion may cause significant damage. Thus important understand response energetic materials thermal insults safe handling storage energetic materials. There extensive study thermal decomposition thermal explosion violence energetic materials elevated temperatures different confinements sample geometries Thermal explosion studies various energetic materials two-dimensional geometry Scaled-Thermal-Explosion-Experiment system5 Sandia-Instrumented-ThermalIgnition SITI system previously reported6. The ODTX system Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory LLNL used decades cook-off study7-11. It attractive due minimal sample requirement 2 grams ODTX shot. The ODTX testing generates three technical data 1 lowest temperature thermal explosion would occur threshold temperature Tli 2 times thermal explosion temperatures Tli calculation activation energy frequency factor 3 thermal explosion violence. It useful tool characterization new energetic materials routinely LLNL Experiments Results Energetic materials spherical cavity configurations except gaseous samples tested ODTX system. An aluminum shell used hold powder samples pasty samples liquid samples. Pressed cast samples delivered cavity aluminum anvils directly without use aluminum shell. The testing involves heating 1.27-cm diameter spherical aluminum anvils. The delivered anvil cavity via sample delivery system predetermined temperature. A microphone sensor measures sound signal indicates time thermal explosion occurs. We present experimental investigation initiation bare uncovered Composition B-3 Comp B-3 explosive impact nosed rods. Comp B-3 contains wax whereas 1 wax used Composition B formulations. Experiments conducted using single-stage gas-gun. Barton John E. Reaugh Laurence E. Fried Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Livermore CA Abstract. The formation hot spots critical shock wave initiation heterogeneous high explosive materials. Hot spots formed example micron-sized pores contained within energetic crystals collapsed shock wave loading. In work numerical model used simulate pore collapse chemical reactions shockloaded -HMX crystal. The model accounts anisotropic time-dependent mechanical responses crystalline phase ii crystal melting due localized deformation iii temperature-driven decomposition reactions. For baseline set model parameters simulations predict modest extent reaction nanosecond time scale. However relatively small increases assumed viscosity liquid phase lead signicant increases reactivity due intensied dissipation shear banding regions. The shock wave initiation heterogeneous high explosive HE materials known controlled localized regions elevated temperature i.e. hot spots 1 2. The hot spots generated example interaction shock wave material defects. Microscopic pores contained within HE crystals among aggregates crystals long considered sources hot spots needed trigger rapid chemical reactions shock wave loading. Therefore descriptions shock wave ignition typically linked pore closure. However fundamental understanding ignition process still lacking precise localization mechanisms microstructure dependencies ignition time scales largely unknown. To improve understanding shock wave initiation HE crystals need resolve dissipative processes give rise hot spots subsequent chemical responses regions. Given difculty accessing relevant time length scales experimental methods pursued computational approach. In regard numerical model developed simulate shock initiation porous -HMX crystal. The model unique accounts crystal mechanics i.e. anisotropic thermoelasticviscoplastic responses crystalline phase ii decomposition reactions driven local temperature. The model used study collapse single pore contained crystal shock-loaded 10 GPa. The reactivity sample quantied post-collapse simulation time nanoseconds time scale short relevant early stages ignition. A small parametric study undertaken assess model sensitivity initial crystal orientation viscosity molten HMX. The stable phase HMX standard pressure temperature phase. phase exhibits monoclinic crystal symmetry represented either two equivalent space groups P 21n P 21c two molecules per unit cell 3. All crystal quantities referenced P 21c space group work. In following describe material model developed address ignition -HMX crystal shock wave loading. Let us begin considering decomposition chemistry. A number multi-step reaction pathways proposed thermal initiation -HMX slow heating processes 46. However reaction path followed shock wave loading involves high pressures short time scales largely unknown. Given uncertainty adopted single-step global reaction. The reaction addresses decomposition - liquid-phase HMX i.e. In scheme chemical species tracked HMX liquid product gas. The reaction rate taken rst-order respect HMX species Arrhenius kinetic parameters Henson et al. 6 utilized i.e. activation energy Ea 149 kJmol frequency factor k0 5.61012 s1. Although singlestep reaction simplication actual chemistry sufcient describe wide range experimentally-measured ignition times including observations relevant shock ignition HMX crystal 6. Future efforts may consider multi-step reactions nal products contain water vapor instead free oxygen. With reaction path kinetics hand various components material model may formulated. The thermoelastic-viscoplastic responses phase handled using crystal model developed previous work 7. The crystal model makes use Murnaghan equation-of-state EOS dislocation density based strength law. In framework plastic deformation crystal phase occurs mo tion dislocations specic slip systems. Selected properties used simulate phase given Table 1. These properties reported standard temperature pressure. To allow crystal melting compression-dependent melt energy curve dened. The liquid viscosity taken constant equal value computed atomistic simulations performed 800 K 1 atm i.e. 5.5 cP 8. Summary conclusions A numerical model used study shock wave initiation porous -HMX crystal. The model calculations situated length scale individual HE grains focus resolving hot spots generated collapse intragranular pores attendant chemical reactions To obtain baseline set results pore collapse -HMX crystal reference case considered. The reference case involved 1-m diameter pore shock loading normal 111 peak stress 9.4 GPa. The reference case yielded modest extent reaction 0.1 post-collapse simulation time nanoseconds. These calculations also revealed importance shear localization deformation mode defective crystal. The shear bands lled molten HMX tend propagate along crystal planes well-oriented slip. Simulations performed assess sensitivity model initial crystal orientation viscosity liquid-HMX phase. For loading normal 111 simulated reactivity relatively insensitive changes twist angle shock direction. It remains seen result holds shocks propagated normal crystal planes. On hand model predictions reactivity quite sensitive viscosity liquid phase. When liquid viscosity increased 5.5 cP 22.0 cP overall reactivity increases rather sharply due occurrence decomposition reactions shear bands. Shock wave ignition nearly achieved sample higher liquid viscosity 0.8 In consideration results future modeling work seek develop accurate treatments liquid phase EOS viscosity. A relatively straight-forward extension current model would incorporate aforementioned temperature-dependent viscosity 8 uid constitutive model. Data pressure dependence liquid viscosity also wanted simulations involve pressures order 10 GPa. Finally techniques extending shock simulation time beyond nanoseconds needed point heat transfer away hot spots addressed. With cylindrical void filled entrained DMF solvent found hot spot much smaller hot spot increasing DMF density. The authors thank Prof. Adri van Duin providing HNS ReaxFF force field description. This study focuses effects two sources material stochasticity random morphology fluctuations interfacial strengthon probability ignition PBXs impact loading. The probabilistic variations time criticality due source quantified. To understand different sources combine affect overall ignition behavior developed nested superposition model. The nested probability model based two layers probability parameters one layer determined layer. Results show model captures interactions two sources variations material attributes. As example application nested probability model data obtained crushing experiment catalyst particles reported literature analyzed. Electronic mail sbasteallnl.govShock-Pressure Pseudo-Entropic Approaches Explosive Initiation Modeling Dynamic Science Incorporated Phoenix AZ Abstract. The hot-spot paradigm explosive shock initiation implies overall rate reaction per unit mass depends number hot spots per unit mass average surface area per hot spot rate surface regresses. In order improve capabilities History Variable Reactive Burn HVRB model CTH hydrocode extensions treat short duration shock waves shock desensitization implemented. As formulated HVRB burn rate pressure dependent explicit representation hot-spot density. The Phase I extension HVRB separates hot-spot density function shock pressure surface regression rate function local pressure. The Phase II extension introduces pseudo-entropy reaction rate depends way preserves single shock response modeling desensitization multiple shock environment. Predictive improvements modeling response short pulses produced thin flyers capabilities represent desensitization double shock reflected shock opposing shocks demonstrated. Critique State Art Phenomenological Modeling The hot-spot paradigm provides generalized phenomenological models explosives shock waves summarized follows action shock wave heterogeneous explosive produces numerous small volumes elevated temperatures hot spots stated without reference specific mechanisms may create hot spots reaction originates hot spots transitions surface burning. The overall rate reaction per unit mass product number hot spots per unit mass hot-spot density average surface area per hot spot rate surface The ideal model simple lends physical interpretation follows hotspot paradigm captures observed phenomena. Existing models less ideal. They may simple enough facilitate calibration especially quick results number new materials needed. They may follow hot-spot paradigm incompletely cases all. applicability model additional observed phenomena accomplished via modifications introduction new models. This process far complete. Among phenomena still need addressed associated complex shock environments response desensitization associated multiple-shock loading. Models may classified single-step multiple-step. Representative single-step models include Forest Fire1 Ignition Growth2 History Variable Reactive Burn HVRB3 used CTH4 hydrocode. Multiple-step models use initial step representing rate hot-spot creation. The chemical reaction step depends evolving hot spot variable. An early example Johnson-Tang-Forest56 model ignition hot spots represented first step continuation completion reaction second step. A recent example Statistical Hot Spot model.7 The general form taken many singlestep models consists one terms describing evolution reaction progress variaEOHXVXDOOUHSUHVHQWLQJWKHSURGXFWPDVV fraction. Each term includes mass-fractiondependent function representing burning topology average surface area per hot spot statedependent function representing combined hot-spot density surface These models follow complete hot-spot paradigm lump effects surface regression hot spot density single factor. A typical pressure-dependent form lumped factor written model used surface regression propellants low pressures pressure exponent neighborhood unity. In order match sustained shock results explosive initiation pressure exponent must significantly higher. This causes reaction rate drop quickly rarefactions regression rate ought decrease hot-spot density not. Pulsed Shock Loading The effect rarefactions dominates initiation explosives thin flyers. Thus directly probing fast chemical reactions either experimentally computationally conditions typically encountered detonation physics feasible. The standard paradigm detonation physics based Chapman-Jouguet theory CJ relies assumptions instantaneous chemical reactions planar infinitely thin shock fronts. This theory employed great success many ideal explosives. For non-ideal explosives explosives charge diameter near critical dimensions assumption breaks hydrodynamics reaction rates starts play determining detonation Here present new bottom-up approach utilizing basic information gleamed fundamental simulations andor experiments e.g. chemical reaction rates possible predict various detonation properties. In particular employ simplified reaction kinetics coupled accurate equation state code Cheetah linked scalable hydrodynamic code ALE3D.2-4 We expect approach able predict detonation properties ideal non-ideal explosives ranging large charge diameters dimensions. In typical simulations bed impacted thin flying plate drives shock wave material. Continuum reactive burn models widely used hydrocodes numerical simulation shock-to-detonation transition heterogeneous energetic materials. Properly calibrated burn models provide satisfactory performance many applications provided approximation valid problem hand. In cases approximation becomes poor. For size volume elements within example duration incident shock pulse short relative size microstructural features approximation may give poor results. Similarly computational mesh approaching length scale microstructural computational domain truly continuum. In heterogeneous materials initiation chemical reactions believed occur defects shock energy create voids cracks grain boundaries discontinuity local temperature pressure far exceed bulk average. Grainscale so-called mesoscale models provided insight heterogeneities conditions favorable onset reactions. Throughout years models varying complexity developed ranging simple geometries single spherical voids12 highly detailed geometries including large ensembles neat3 plastic-bonded4 explosive grains. Those simulations typically limited unit cells representative volume elements capture statistical behavior shock response bed inadequate directly simulate complete transition Numerical simulations detonation significant practical application. Conclusions Future Study We developed model shock-todetonation transition porous beds granular microstructures first-principles equation state local temperature-dependent reaction kinetics. discontinuities microstructure voids explicitly geometry. The model directly simulates deformation heating solid matrix subsequent release chemical energy progression reactive flow field quasisteady detonation conditions. temperature-dependent specific heat material strength pore geometry demonstrated simulations individual voids. These studies illustrated several areas accuracy model improved. First strength solid material micro-scale dynamic loading conditions poorly understood. Our results showed even inclusion simple elastic-perfectly plastic model relatively low yield strength significantly affect predicted temperature solid. This turn directly affects rate chemical energy release. Refinement strength models critical achieving accurate predictions The second area improvement reaction mechanisms thermodynamic conditions rate chemical The kinetics may complicated single-step Arrhenius kinetic rate assumed here. We currently investigating shock-induced chemistry HNS materials plan incorporate results model become available. A third topic investigation validity continuum hydrocode sub-micron length scale. Large-scale reactive molecular dynamics simulations approaching length scale1617 may eventually overlap lower end continuum models using molecular dynamics techniques would represent major step forward energetic materials research. Despite areas improvements modeling approach presented useful tool studying role microstructure initiation behavior heterogeneous explosives. Despite decades research chemical processes states matter govern behavior energetic materials detonation conditions well understood including molecular level processes determine decomposition kinetics energy release. Oxygen content often employed simple intuitive guide development practical use explosives effect detonation chemistry remains little studied especially case oxygen overabundance. To end conducted quantum molecular dynamics QMD simulations zero oxygen balance oxygen-rich mixtures hydrogen peroxide nitromethane detonation-like conditions near equilibrium time-scales. We nd excellent agreement extrapolated chemical equilibrium properties thermochemical models zero oxygen balance mixture. In contrast oxygen-rich mixture observe formation nitrogen oxide intermediates particularly nitrate ions NO3 effectively act oxygennitrogen trap precluding formation equilibrium products N2 CO2. Our results could implications design modeling oxygen-rich energetics common military industrial use. Explosive materials generally contain oxidizing oxygen-rich reducing oxygen-poor groups high pressure temperature conditions typical detonation shock wave produce small gaseous products low heats 1. Deformation H2O N2 CO CO2 spite extensive production practical use numerous industrial military applications2 basic microscopic properties many energetic materials shock-induced chemical decomposition well known. Detonation wave reaction times i.e. steady-state reaction zones lengths inferred hydrodynamic measurements anywhere nanosecond microsecond time scales3. However molecular level processes govern extent reaction zone poorly understood many organic materials composites longer time scale kinetics e.g. larger nanoseconds frequently thought result carbon-rich oxygen-poor explosives processes carbon condensation coagulation4 possibly coupled slow CO2 The oxygen balance degree explosive oxidized known correlate well performance5 sensitivity properties6 therefore important metric synthesis new energetic compounds7 8. A convenient avenue controlling oxygen balance energetic mixtures combine oxygen-rich oxygenpoor materials done example widely used ammonium nitrate-fuel oil ANFO formula 930 tion 9. These types mixtures widespread use mining civil construction due low cost relative insensitivity. However oxygenrich mixtures tend exhibit long reaction zones result large failure diameters i.e. minimum charge diameter propagation steady detonation possible10 poor performance. The development use high performance oxidizers mixtures remain much interest variety applications including civil engineering rocket propellants munitions11 would directly benet fundamental understanding chemical reactivity extreme conditions encountered Molecular dynamics MD simulations provide independent route chemical speciation occurs detonation-like conditions could facilitate future design use energetic materials. Accurate modeling breaking formation chemical bonds behind shock front frequently requires use quantum theory12 13 density functional tight binding14 DFTB. DFTB self-consistent atomic charges SCC approximate quantum simulation technique allows several orders magnitude increase computational efciency retaining accuracy standard quantum simulations e.g. Kohn-Sham Density Functional Theory DFT15. This allows DFTB simulations achieve close equilibrium timescales long-timescale reactivity e.g. several hundred picoseconds greater13 whereas DFT-MD calculations generally limited tens picoseconds16 far equilibrium similar conditions12. DFTB shown provide accurate descriptions chemical reactivity number systems extreme conditions including nitromethane17 organic materials18 19. Recently DFTB used validate equation state decomposition kinetics hydrogen peroxide H2O2 detonation conditions picosecond timeresolved shock compression experiments20. In work predict entirely new mechanism slow chemical reactivity nitrogencontaining oxygen-balanced oxygen-rich explosive mixtures detonation conditions using DFTB quantum simulation method. We focus liquid explosives choose hydrogen peroxide nitromethane prototypical energetic materials excess decit oxygen respectively. Our simulations consisted 6040 molar ratio zero oxygen balance 8020 molar ratio positive oxygen balance mixtures hydrogen peroxidenitromethane detonation-like conditions. Zero oxygen balance corresponds mixture exactly enough oxygen turn carbon CO2 hydrogen H2O positive oxygen balance corresponds system surfeit oxygen 5.. We rst validate results thermodynamic properties mixture results equation state EOS chemical equilibrium models21. We analyze long timescale chemical reactivity mixtures nd rate formation end products CO2 especially N2 determined part slow kinetics nitrogen oxide intermediates. This leads striking result oxygenrich mixture nitrate NO3 acts major nitrogen oxygen trap leading long-lived likely metastable thermodynamic state. Our results help elucidate properties types materials extreme conditions including reaction zones could useful guiding Computational Methods Direct chemical equilibrium calculations performed mixtures using methodology outlined Ref.21. In calculations individual molecular products modeled exp6polar interactions parameterized wide range experimental data e.g. static dynamic pressure experiments sound speed measurements system thermodynamics derived using statistical mechanics techniques. This approach proved successful predicting properties variety reactive materials high pressures temperatures including shock Hugoniots detonation velocities22. DFTB-SCC calculations driven LAMMPS molecular software simulation suite23 DFTB code24 used compute forces cell stress tensor. We used C-H-O-N interaction parameters available download mio-0-1 parameter set httpwww.dftb.org. The maximum number SCC steps MD time step reduced four use Extended Lagrangian Born-Oppenheimer molecular dynamics XL-BOMD approach propagation electronic degrees freedom25. Thermal populations excited electronic states computed Mermin functional26. All simulations discussed performed time-step 0.2 fs allowed simulation conserved quantities maintain constant value. The zero oxygen balance mixture set 36 H2O2 24 CH3NO2 molecules 312 atoms total. Zero pressure optimization produced computational-cell lattice vectors 23.9961 b 11.9980 c 11.9980 yielding initial density 1.29 gcm3 compared EOS computed value 1.26 . The positive oxygen balance mixture contained 72 H2O2 12 CH3NO2 molecules 276 atoms. This optimized lattice vectors 22.7646 b 11.3823 c 11.3823 yielding initial density 1.33 gcm3 EOS computed value. Each initial mixture equilibrated 300 K 10 ps using NoseHoover thermostat chains27 28. Uniaxial compression due shock wave occurred along lattice vector. Previous work shown doubling system size along lattice vector similar system size yielded virtually identical thermodynamic conditions shock loading12. Shock compression simulations conducted using well-established Multi-scale Shock compression Simulation Technique MSST29. MSST operates time-evolving equations motion atoms computational cell dimension direction shock constrain stress propagation direction Rayleigh line energy system Hugoniot energy condition. For given shock speed two relations describe steady planar shock wave within continuum theory. MSST used conjunction quantum simulation methods accurately reproduce shock Hugoniot number systems e.g. Ref.20. For shock velocities used scaling term MSST ionic equations motion account drift conserved quantity simulations13. A scaling factor 104 resulted deviation total forces simulations less 1 steady shock com pression produced. Jackson12 Bono Wasistho1 John Buckmaster3 1Illinois Rocstar LLC Champaign IL 61820 2Center Compressible Multiphase Turbulence University Florida Gainesville FL 32611 3Buckmaster Research Abstract. When shock wave passes energetic material detonation wave form. One potential cause transition detonation formation local regions high temperature hot-spots within explosive due presence micron-scale voids. As shock wave passes material voids collapse resulting local increase temperature potentially localized ignition. These regions local ignition combine form detonation wave eventually overtakes original shock. As realistic models formation hot-spots pivotal performing predictive numerical simulations shock-to-detonation transition. Fully resolving hot-spots numerically computationally prohibitive mesh resolution required several orders magnitude smaller required macroscale even mesoscale simulations. Instead present subgrid hot-spot model derived numerical simulations void collapse hot-spot formation. The model provides energy release source dependent strength shock initial size void. The model also provides information time required hot-spot activation induction time nal void size ignition. The model implemented mesoscale simulation code RocSDT3D used demonstrate shock-to-detonation transition realistic mesoscale HMX crystal pack generated packing code Rocpack. There extensive development burn models currently use empirical ad hoc hotspot parameterizations so-called ignition-andgrowth approaches. Previously explored effects hot-spots implementing one ad hoc model modifies local density according size hot-spot proximity1. In model local density modified computing distance hotspot. The influence hot-spot surrounding material defined hot-spot extent. We used model explore effects hot-spot packing density size explosive packs. We shown model reproduces trends observed experimentally2 Published Office Naval Research Proceedings 15th International Detonation Symposium. parameters required match transition following sections present rigorous physics-based subgrid hot-spot model simulations spherical void collapse explosive crystals using newlydeveloped code RocSVC. The model prescribes time-dependent energy release due hot-spot accounts varying pore size shock pressure. This model superior previous density drop model simulations recreate complex dynamics pore collapse. As result new model important step toward predictively modeling shock detonation transition mesoscale. Physics-based Pore Collapse Model In Borne experiments2 wave transient time across cylindrical sample diameter 42 mm length 50 mm approximately 8 Ps. This time corresponds case shock transitioned detonation wave. Thus dynamics associated hot-spot formation ignition must timescale much shorter 8 Ps. Additionally Menikoff3 states For strong shock P 10 GPa note approximately 200 ns. Hot-spots must react fast timescale say within 20 In addition Menikoff showed numerically plastic work viscous heating necessary dissipative mechanisms peak temperatures generated void collapse reach beyond 1000 K critical temperature needed initiation i.e. shock dissipation alone sufficient initiation chemical reaction take place. The results void collapse model presented consistent experiments Borne work Menikoff. Spherical Void Collapse shock traveling time order void collapse void collapses asymmetrically. To describe events full numerical simulations must carried out2. For void diameters less 10 microns shock traveling time much faster pore collapse time shock assumed pass pore instantaneously setting hydrostatic pressure field material surrounding pore. In case pore assumed collapse symmetrically model derived describe events. RocSVC developed symmetric collapse spherical void. It includes effects mass heat transfer pore surrounding condensate boundary two. The condensate treated incompressible pressure pore treated uniform. The governing equations cast spherical coordinates reference frame follows evolving boundary pore gas condentate. The result fastrunning 1-D code used generate hundreds simulation results form basis analytic hot-spot model. Fig. 1 provides illustration problem configuration. A shock traveling right speed D. The RocSDT3D code fully three-dimensional uses Cartesian finite volume framework solve Euler equations. The solver also parallelized using MPI framework designed distributed memory platforms. The user select arbitrary number processors used three space directions. The physics models included RocSDT3D following governed Euler equations reactive medium HLLC- Harten Riemann solver shock capturing. The various parameters defined models listed Table 2 well allowable ranges assumed work. The ARB model15 incorporates temperaturedependent Arrhenius rate law. The parameters F T0 Table 2 Parameter limits reactive models g1 MBar-y1us-1 2-1.5 0.0232 0.0250.3 0.5 parameter included optimization used fit experimental data well threshold temperature Ti reaction rate set zero. The HVRB model15 incorporates pressuredependent rate law time delay initiation rapid reaction. The rate equation model follows17 O extent reaction I integral time pressure P mass point sec used make I dimensionless. The five parameters PI PR Z M X used fit experimental data. The rate equation IGRB model written follows17 O extent reaction U U0 initial current densities respectively s0 parameters 3 constraints used fit experimental data. Description HERMES model We developed HERMES model High Explosive Response MEchanical Stimulus describe deformation ignition post-ignition pressure build-up occur explosive assemblies subjected impacts. We used model describe HEVR High Explosive Violent Response occur Steven spigot intrusion tests. In tests mechanical insult strong enough induce prompt detonation. It embedded Livermore Softwares LS-DYNA15 Lawrence Livermore National Laboratorys ALE3D16 computer simulation programs userdefined material UMAT. The two stresses proportional area fraction solid. Throughout model assumed volume area fractions species equal. This similar effective stress used soil mechanics water-saturated soils. The shear strength solid borne matrix. If expansion exceeds specified maximum value matrix pressure shear strength zero. Simulations response large charges We investigated hypothetical large cylindrical charge geometry using baseline material LX04 molding powder beads pressed 15 porosity. We conclude model correct rather may used guide designing next set experiments. Summary equations solved HERMES A recent report33 summarizes equations solved current version HERMES. Revisions model subsequent publication report two categories modifications needed use ALE 3D including advection bug fixes. The present versions use input flag specify computer simulation program exercised. In way minimal number source code modifications needed moving one simulation program other. This trades convenience developer presence blocks coding used given simulation program. Hull James E. Kennedy Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos New Mexico 87545 USA Abstract. The constant volume explosion CVE discussed community many years. It suggested thought experiment book entitled Detonation Fickett Davis process could understood limit infinite detonation velocity. This approach would yield high detonation pressure contrast conversationally taken somewhere near usual detonation pressure. In work rigorously show CVE pressure indeed near detonation pressure resulting process expands manner similar expansion detonation state. We show power deposition required cause CVE uniform non-uniform cases. This requirement quite severe high giga- terawatt GW TW range. Finally hydrodynamic analysis shows copper cylinder wall accelerate similar velocity regardless process. However early time motion differs significantly. instantaneous conversion stationary constant volume explosive gas heat fundamentally different problem well understood detonation process one may produce similar effects surroundings. Detonation Modeling Peridynamic Theory Sandia National Laboratories Albuquerque NM 87185 Abstract. Peridynamic theory theory continuum mechanics formulated terms integro-differential equations without spatial derivatives. Its equations remain valid regardless fractures discontinuities may emerge material due loading. This theory provides consistent treatment deformation failure materials dynamic loading. In bond-based peridynamics material properties specified pairwise force function. We apply work-energy theorem obtain pairwise force function gas. With gas detonation products represented peridynamic materials use Zeldovich Von Neumann Doering detonation model volume-burn algorithm formulate detonation model peridynamic theory. We discuss numerical method implementation detonation model concomitant addressing time-step stability short-range forces. Finally illustrate formulation simulations cylinder-expansion test cylinder fragmenting explosive loading. Its equations remain valid regardless fractures discontinuities may emerge material due loading. PD provides consistent treatment deformation failure materials dynamic loading. Peridynamic Detonation Model In section discuss propagation detonation initiation points equations state EOSs detonation products summarize implementation detonation model. Propagation Detonation Program Burn The detonation times must determined node containing explosive. These times input processing using Huygens construction procedure. This method called program burn. Program burn proceeds follows. There set nodes whose detonation times specified user input. Initial detonation times nodes initially set large number. The construction proceeds sweeping grid examining node detonation times nodes spherical neighborhood node. The detonation time node smallest time detonation propagate detonated node neighborhood node. This process continues detonation times computed nodes. This Huygens construction procedure insures detonations propagate around obstacles isolated regions explosive material detonate. However obstructions isolated regions explosive detonation radius may specified. In case detonation time particular node minimum times detonation propagate along straight line initially detonating nodes node.
