Summary Conclusions In paper described detonation model peridynamic theory PD. After concise discussion aspects bond-based PD numerical method needed completeness showed represent gases PD materials deriving pairwise force function PFF gas. This derivation based work-energy theorem. The volume burn algorithm discussed. This algorithm statement conservation energy detonation products provides reference pressure use pressure isentropes needed gas PFF. This algorithm based ZND detonation model. Time-step stability addressed since essential obtain solutions PD equation obtained needed provide solutions explosive material changes solid gas undergoes expansion. We discussed shortrange forces. These forces prevent bonds indefinitely violating nonimpenetrability matter. They responsible loading solid material expanding gas. Without forces expanding gas would simply diffuse solid. We provided outline details implementing PD detonation model computer code. Finally expanding-cylinder fragmenting-cylinder tests. The simulation results excellent agreement data. We conclude PD detonation model described paper viable technology studying explosive loading. c Damage stretch coefficient minimum stretch coefficient models used steel. These models increase critical damage increases compression respectively. Reply Paul Demmie A laboratory tested steel provided true stress versus true strain curve. We used true strain failure 0.11 critical stretch simulation. This curve also provided yield strength 750 MPa steel. The laboratory also provided bulk modulus density used determine bulk sound speed. Implications Mesoscale Phenomena Modelling Shock Detonation Transition Continuum Scale Brian D Lambourn Caroline A Handley Heather J Lacy AWE Aldermaston Reading Berkshire RG7 4PR U.K. Abstract. At mesoscale heterogeneous explosives reaction proceeds burning individual hotspots whereas continuum level reactive burn model needs represent integrated effect burning many hotspots. Recent mesoscale calculations show near pressure equilibrium reaction products yet unreacted explosive temperatures densities significantly different. Other authors shown reaction rate continuum level depends number density hotspots burn speed. It argued hotspot number density depends shock strength represented non-reacted entropy mesoscale calculations show reaction products temperature best correlates burn front speed. By comparing results mesoscale calculation continuum level calculation shown two temperature ISE model reasonable approximation continuum level partially reacted equation state. To end Hill Zimmermann Nichols1 continuum scale reaction rate burn fronts propagating distribution hotpots showed reaction rate depends number density hotspots power burn speed. The overall extent reaction depends burning adjacent hotspots inter-hotspot distances microns burn front speeds typically ms. However shown earlier paper3 time ignition hotspots pressure hence hydrodynamic parameters influenced burning hotspots millimetres away. In shock detonation transition SDT heterogeneous explosive generally agreed shock wave interacts defects explosive microstructure form small regions high temperature called hotspots sufficiently large hot react times much less 1s shock passed timescale relevant SDT. Reaction heat conduction drive burn fronts hotspot surrounding shocked explosive consumed. The critical point details reaction chemistry burning phenomena occurring mesoscale whereas reactive burn model continuum level needs represent integrated sum burning multitude mesoscale hotspots. The aim paper examine implications mesoscale physics description form reactive burn model studying SDT take continuum scale including properties adopted partially reacted equation state EOS model. A simple analytic hydrodynamic model developed mesoscale hydrocode calculations carried study hydrodynamic fields developed single isolated hotspot integrated states distribution hotspots. The questions addressed How overall reaction build How pressure temperature build continuum scale? What determines number density active hotspots reactive burn front What model used partially reacted EOS continuum scale? Reaction Rate Burning Distribution Hill et al1 assumed spherical burn fronts propagate constant speed point hotspots activated simultaneously time zero used probability argument allow fact burn fronts would overlap. Calculational Methods The simple analytic model assumes reaction instantaneous burn front speed constant. By linearising equations motion equations state problem single isolated hotspot reduced solving wave equation using velocity potential method. It follows pressure field point within distribution hotspots found summing contributions pressures hotspot. Allowance made effect overlapping hotspots using method applied Hill et al1. Since pressure field hotspot grows sound speed summation carried radius millimetres. The mesoscale calculations used 1D Lagrangian hydrocode incorporating Arrhenius kinetics heat conduction4. A Linear Grneisen EOS used non-reacted HMX constant Grneisen Gamma specific heat constant volume cvs. A JWL EOS used reaction products constant specific heat constant volume cvg. Local pressure temperature equilibrium assumed partially reacted EOS. A constant value thermal conductivity k used. The NR DP EOS independent. For example problems arise NR DP Hugoniots cross. It shown reference 5 reaction remain exothermic DP EOS surface pressure p specific volume v specific internal energy e space must lie NR EOS surface v e. In addition experience continuum reactive burn model CREST6 shown strong coupling overall EOS reaction rate. It concluded ISE model gives reasonable representation implications mesoscale calculation therefore appropriate use continuum level reactive burn models Discussion Conclusions Modelling shock detonation transition heterogeneous explosives different kind mesoscale continuum scale. processes reaction burning hotspots occur mesoscale. Reactive burn continuum integrated effects distribution hotspots. Consequently form reaction rate aspects equation state model continuum level quite different mesoscale. At mesoscale plausible use Arrhenius kinetics pressure appropriate continuum level By considering burning constant speed hotspot spatial distribution hotspots Hill et al1 Menikoff Shaw2 shown integrated reaction rate continuum level function number density hotspots speed burn fronts. The resulting reaction rate history grows peak decays zero quite different shape Arrhenius reaction rate. The shape reaction rate similarities used CREST6 example given reference 7. It plausible assume number density active hotpots dependent shock strength. There various ways defining shock strength example using pressure density neither predict effect changing initial density initial temperature. The solution CREST reactive burn model found successful many situations use entropy non-reacted explosive. Shock Compression Condensed Matter 2009 pp. 432-435 AIP 1195 2009. Arrhenius kinetics heat conduction shown burn front speed best correlates temperature reaction products behind burn front figure 9. Using analytic model mesoscale calculations shown pressure generated isolated hotspot tiny temperature difference reaction products non-reacted explosive large. The width hydrodynamic field isolated hotspot grows sound speed c around thousand times burn front speed. At continuum level overall pressure distribution hotspots summation contributions hotspots sphere radius ct. In gas gun shock initiation geometry includes hotspots interface flyer point ahead shock front. With small oscillations pressure uniform across reaction products non-reacted explosive. By contrast density temperature products reactants quite different. A partially reacted EOS continuum scale therefore needs pressure-equilibrium two-density two-temperature model suggests use Cowperthwaiites ISE model8. A comparison figures 10 12 ISE calculation continuum scale confined hotspot calculation mesoscale shown reasonable agreement. improved equations hydrocode calculations. For example relaxing assumption constant specific heat would significantly reduce non-reacted temperature. More complicated reaction rates also need examined e.g. endothermic precursor reaction. Mesoscale arguments presented form solid basis development next generation reactive-burn models. Due low manufacturing cost ease handling low risk accidental ignition ammonium-nitrate-fuel-oil ANFO remains one popular mining explosives present. The non-ideal detonation behaviour ammonium-nitrate-based explosives lead detonation velocities low one-third ideal velocity. A model PETN developed using CREST reactive burn model. It also intended work feed High Explosive Violent Response model HERMES purpose explosive safety assessment understanding ageing mechanisms. The CREST reactive burn parameters tuned several sets experimental data. CREST uses snowplough model account initial density explosive. In past within 90 TMD. The densities PETN interest us less 80 TMD. The reaction rate parameters tuned published experimental wedge test data in-material manganin gauge data. We demonstrate certain reaction rate parameters affect fit experimental Pop-plot data. This model still development unable find single set reaction rate parameters fit Pop-plots PETN required densities. Pure PETN white granular explosive widely used within detonator systems depending upon use pressed wide range densities less 50 TMD theoretical maximum density within 90 TMD. Like many explosives PETN becomes sensitive lower densities1 higher specific surface area SSA2. The reaction zone duration detonating PETN inferred Fabry-Perot studies PETN close TMD less 10ns3. This implies reaction rate PETN extremely fast compared secondary explosives HMX The aim work develop model Computational Reaction Evolution dependent Entropy S Time CREST reactive burn model5. It also intended work feed High Explosive Violent Response HEVR model HERMES High Explosive Response MEchanical Stimulus capable modeling SDT DDT. In addition HERMES uses CREST regimes pressure burning explosive causes shock form. HERMES previously used success modeling DDT HMX based explosive EDC376 experiments reverse detonation also called retonation reproduced. In future work help develop HERMES model characteristics run distance curvature detonation wave dead zones effects aim model correctly. CREST previously shown versatile model used simulate phenomena. A variety explosives modeled using CREST PBX95017 PBX95028 LX-179 UF-TATB. These explosives modeled densities within 90 TMD using entropy dependent reaction rate. CREST based observation reaction rate depends local shock strength led conclusion function entropy explosive determines Whilst CREST shown accurate several explosives models constructed using suite high-fidelity experimental data SDT detonation. In particular reaction rate model tuned embedded gauge data gas-gun firings589. Pop-plots given density provide far less calibrating empirical reaction rate equations. Handley shown CREST reaction rates tuned reproduce particle velocity traces gas-gun shots8. A tuned reaction rate coefficient set suitable densities near TMD eliminating need re-calibrate parameters new density9. However CREST yet shown scale densities 90 TMD. embedded gauge data A literature review found experimental data PETN various densities terms nonreacted Hugoniot data1101112. There also includes significant amounts data regarding change detonation pressure velocity PETN density collated Hornig et al.13 reanalyzed Green et al.14. However significantly less embedded gauge data needed tune CREST reaction rate parameters. Wedge test experiments primary source data available PETN shock initiation. This study addresses stability sonic points origin internal shocks double-front detonations using Ficketts detonation analogue. Since reaction phases exothermic detonation wave sustained either one energy release steps. Experiments numerical simulations shown selection rules detonation wave pressure proles depend intimately kinetics reactions either phase amount energy release hydrodynamic resistance particles gas phase motion Zhangs recent review provides state-of-the-art1. Typically solid phase entrained shocked gas phase usually also reacts faster. The solid phase extracts momentum via drag forces energy via heat conduction work done drag forces The competition heat addition en ergy loss dictates structure self-sustained wave. At so-called generalized Chapman-Jouget CJ conditions zero net thermicity forward facing characteristics amplify thus serve limiting characteristics. steady travelling detonation solutions established sonic planes propagate precisely speed lead shock given accumulated energy release two surfaces. In systems many reactions occur separately concurrently losses hybrid detonations subclass several zero-thermicity points exist locations exothermic reactions balance losses. They found range conditions detonation would suddenly accelerate quasi-steady propagation velocity faster one. Longbottom David L. Frost Jason Loiseau Samuel Goroshin Fluid Gravity Engineering Ltd. St. Andrews Fife UK KY16 8YG McGill University Mechanical Engineering Dept. Montreal QC Canada H3A 0C3 Carleton University Mechanical Aerospace Eng. Ottawa ON Canada K1S 5B6 University St. Andrews Mathematical Institute St. Andrews UK KY16 9SS Abstract. Rapid acceleration spherical shell liquid following detonation high explosive causes liquid form fine jets similar appearance particle jets formed explosive dispersal packed layer solid particles. Of particular interest determining dependence scale jet-like structures physical parameters system including fluid properties e.g. density viscosity surface tension ratio mass liquid explosive. The present paper presents computational results multimaterial hydrocode describing dynamics explosive dispersal process. The computations used track overall features dispersal liquid layer including wave dynamics motion spall accretion layers. The results compared experimental results spherical charges containing variety different fluids including water glycerol ethanol vegetable oil together encompass significant range fluid properties. The results show number jet structures sensitive fluid properties primarily dependent mass ratio. Above certain mass ratio liquid fill explosive burster FB number jets approximately constant consistent empirical model based maximum thickness accretion layer. For small values FB number liquid jets reduced contrast explosive powder dispersal small FB yields larger number particle jets. Detonation central high explosive charge surrounded shell material common practical geometry many application areas physics interaction detonation surrounding material continues studied. These areas include blast mitigation fuel-air explosions metalized explosives reactive casings. In paper consider shell liquid surrounding explosive charge spherical geometry. The behaviour following detonation high explosive charge underwater studied detail many years see example Cole1. A detonation deep water considered case shell water infinite thickness conditions one observes growth oscillation stable gas bubble. There many examples phenomenon illustrate behaviour Fig. 1 recent results kindly supplied us Kirkpatrick Fig. 1. Underwater bubble detonation 10 g aluminized explosive charge thin plastic case cylindrical tank various times left right top bottom. In figure one see detonation followed initial expansion observed may correspond case effects later times one observe smooth stable gas globe characteristic phase underwater If consider shell water finite thickness introduction outer boundary changes stability system. In case outer liquid surface longer stable forms jet-like structures suggesting strongly wave interactions outer boundary play key role observed break-up process. Milne et al.34 noted dispersal experimental evidence wide range expanding cloud explosively disseminated material comprised particles fragments significantly different dimensions associated original material. Photographic evidence shows expanding fragments. Examples formation jet structures given example liquid particle outer boundary reaches Frost et al.5 Ripley Zhang6 Frost Zhang7 context jet formation heterogeneous blast explosives. X-ray analysis systems allowed Milne et al.4 show fragmentation process occurs early expansion around time release wave surrounding material. They showed number fragments observed early time radiographs late time photographic evidence good agreement. A simple model predict number jets powders proposed. Explosive acceleration liquid shell differs corresponding situation solid particles due presence voids unperturbed particle bed. In latter case shock propagating particles causes considerable compaction depending ductility particles compacted bed may considerable strength compaction. In case shock loading liquid reflection expansion wave liquid surface subsequent tension applied bulk liquid lead cavitation formation void growth subsequent breakup bubbly liquid Explosive dispersal liquid progresses several regimes. In first regime termed ejection regime9 forces associated propagation shock wave liquid rarefaction returns liquid surface dominate motion fluid. This followed transition regime aerodynamic forces liquid. In final regime shock forces decayed aerodynamic drag droplet breakup due competition inertial surface The present work concerned nearfield ejection regime occurs timescale 100s microseconds shock forces dominate. Of particular interest determining dependence scale jet-like structures fluid properties e.g. density viscosity surface tension ratio mass physical parameters liquid explosive. The number liquid jets formed rate droplet shedding subsequent evaporation liquid determine size liquid-vapour-air cloud ultimately formed interest liquid combustible. In present paper dynamics explosive dispersal process investigated multimaterial hydrocode. The computations used track features process including wave dynamics motion spall accretion layers. A working hypothesis dynamic liquid breakup proposed maximum thickness accretion hypothesis examined light experimental results spherical charges containing variety different fluids determine influence fluid properties. Water chosen baseline fluid liquids chosen significant variations fluid properties including glycerol similar density surface tension water much higher viscosity vegetable oil similar density water higher viscosity tension ethanol similar density viscosity water lower surface experimental computational results existing theoretical models describing fragmentation liquids first considered. Theoretical Models Liquid Breakup The dynamic breakup liquids considered theoretically Grady10. He found energy-limited spall liquids dominated surface energy effects low strain rates viscous dissipation high rates. He also noted exists relatively little experimental information liquid spall. His model used estimate order magnitude liquid fragment jet size. Let us compare results Grady model determine estimates fragment size thus number. The Grady model predicts fragment values two limits namely surface tension dominated viscous dissipation dominated. Which mechanism dominant determined spall strength. As surface tension viscosity act stabilize break-up argument presentation dominant mechanism situation one largest spall strength. Effect Surface Tension Grady model predicts fragment size For surface tension dominated problems surface tension density H local strain rate. Effect Viscosity model gives fragment size For viscous dominated problems Grady viscosity. In order track precisely instabilities Refinement strategy used DECO. The AMR package called PARAMESH 21 based D. De Zeeuw K.G. Powell works. The computed domain divided blocks containing fixed number mesh cells. A block refinement consists subdividing factor 12 smaller blocks ones obviously based variable level pressure velocity variable gradient. May Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory 7000 East Avenue Livermore CA 94550 U.S.A. Abstract. A critical mechanism delayed XDT X unknown Detonation Transition modes fragmentation energetic materials high-speed impact loading. Fragment size spacing distribution turn inuence recompaction initiation subsequent detonation propagation XDT. We perform meso-scale simulations examine effects microstructure binder properties impact-induced fragmentation behavior. Such studies provide numerical framework understanding structure-property relationships designing new energetic materials optimized safety properties. We employ multi-physics arbitrary-lagrangian-eulerian code ALE3D 1 simulations. Unreacted equation-of-state properties well strength properties taken previous meso-scale studies HMX. In simulations binder strength varied reect strength commonly used energetic material binders e.g. HTPB Kel-F PTFE Epoxy Estane. HMX grain size distribution volume fraction binder thickness also varied explore microstructural effects. Propellants explosives experienced high velocity insults bullet fragment impacts undergo reactions exhibit delayed transition detonation 2. The associated impact stresses lower time detonation much 100 microseconds much longer durations observed shock-to-detonations SDT occur approximately within rst passing shock front microseconds. type detonation transition referred unknown-to-detonation transition XDT since mechanisms lead detonation entirely known. The common thought however XDT reactions modes result increased sensitivity following propagating pressure front due damage nucleation form porosity In burn-to-violent reaction BVR experiments 3 XDT experiments 4 5 recompaction damaged propellants considered initiation mode leads detonation friction initiation mechanisms 5 explosive grains interact multiple shock wave pass damaged material. The binder believed strong effect mode detonation decohesion explosive grains binder allow grains interact directly loads provide avenue ame propagation. Thus fracturing behavior propellants high explosives important understanding XDT modes steps leading recompaction inside rocket motor boreholes requires examination projectile impact response energetic materials ing violence material based understanding suggests increased binder content reduces either generation damage reducing amount interfaces act decohesion sites increasing materials inherent capability transferring load throughout microstructure dissipating intensity stress causes damage. In mesoscale studies conducted HMXEstane binder formulations 10 materials greater amount binder capable dissipating work done shock front easily. They also found binder temperatures signicantly lower impacts 500 ms 1000 ms. Since polymers temperature strain rate dependent projectile impact velocity may play important role. Therefore study volume fraction binder varied within range 75-95 vol. evaluate similar effects modify fracturing damage behavior due projectile impacts velocities 500 1000 ms. Effects Binder Strength The binders strength characteristics plays key role deformation polymer bonded explosive composites high velocity impacts. For microstructures containing softer binders relation Kel-F HTPB much lower strains binder see histogram Figure 10 HMX grains. The opposite true microstructures stronger materials epoxy. When Kel-F binder replaced epoxy strains within HMX grains increased binder plastic strain histograms broadened signicantly. The propagation failure binder occurred rapidly instances results generation fragments. Not surprisingly decrease velocity 1000 ms 500 ms resulted smaller strains narrow histogram distribution given time. However difference general fairly small may indicative greater dependence binder strength microstructure impact velocity stress magnitudes reach certain level. Conclusions Future Studies Based simulations following generalized trends observed. Firstly increasing amounts binder decreased accumulation strain HMX translated work done binder. In delayed XDT reactions involve types formulations onset ignition may limited conduction heat binder HMX grains. Second larger grain size distributions result deformation HMX binder straining occurring along percolation paths containing larger grains. This results damagefragmentation across entire sample earlier times thereby increasing chances ignition due friction interactions grains secondary impacts fragments surfaces downstream sample rigid surfaces BVR tests two slabs propellant analogous rocket motor bores. Thirdly microstructures HTPB less plastic straining binder HMX grains epoxy increased straining HMX binder. This results generation fewer larger fragments smaller fragments formulations weakerstronger binders respectively. tests smaller gap distances often less chance XDT reactions take place since fragment cloud doesnt chance rarify recompacting. For formulations propellants high explosives may contain stronger binders smaller gap distances may needed reduce chances XDT reaction upon recompaction. In simulations inference fragment production came deformation individual constituents fairly early times. Future simulations address incorporation advanced failure models representative physical observations. They also include anvil varying strength downstream side fragment cloud investigate contributions secondary impacts recompaction projectile anvil XDT modes reaction observed propellants inside rocket bores. Temperature distributions within fragments upon striking anvils monitored. Other topics interest effects porosity fragmentation PBXs high velocity impacts projectiles geometry size. Since fracturing materials threedimensional attributes stress bridging grains simulations also conducted threedimensional microstructures generated manner. Ripley Fan Zhang 1888 Brunswick St. Suite 400 Halifax NS Canada B3J 3J8 Defence RD Canada - Suffield PO Box 4000 Stn Main Medicine Hat AB Canada T1A 8K6 Abstract. Explosive dispersal granular materials liquids displays multiple scales jetting structures smaller perturbations often superimposed larger structures. Perturbations may originate near boundaries booster shock-dispersed media outer edge charge interfaces often feature thin casing material fragments influences instabilities. The present work includes situation particles saturated liquid explosive numerically investigate jetting instability observed premixed particles-explosive configuration. Previous experimental observations thermobaric explosives demonstrated well-defined jetting structures. Macroscopic multiphase flow simulation shows densification jetting particles. Modeling Liquid Explosives In order model liquid explosives ALE3D started incompressible flow model developed model simple fluid flows. require implicit pressure velocity solve. The momentumvelocity field solved second order accurate finite element method resulting non-divergence free intermediate velocity. For robustness strongly varying viscosity viscous terms treated first order accurate backward Euler time integration. The convective terms treated explicitly. Two important phenomena pertinent detonation performance triaminotrinitrobenzene TATB-based explosives detonation wave corner turning shock desensitization. Although studied individually practical applications processes could present concurrently. To address Hart1 conducted interesting series experiments called Jack Rabbit designed study detonation wave corner turning shock desensitization explosive LX-17 92.5 TATB 7.5 Kel-F. Corner turning refers relative inability detonation wave overcome divergence flow caused sudden change propagation direction. TATB-based explosives exhibit relatively long detonation reaction zone lengths 2-3mm.2 As result propagating detonation waves weaken markedly attempting turn sharp corners. This lead sustained non-reacted andor partially reacted pockets explosive dead-zones behind corner turn region.3-6 The first objective Jack Rabbit test ability LX-17 detonation waves propagate around two 90 corners embedded steel plate. The term shock desensitization describes reduced response explosives complex shock loading e.g. shock reflections sequential shocks detonation extinction. Data latter scarce. Campbell Travis7 Dick8 observed detonation waves PBX 9404 94 HMX 3 NC 3 CEF PBX 9502 95 extinguished upon propagating pre-shocked explosive. For Jack Rabbit hypothesized LX-17 detonation waves successfully turned corners embedded plate would run pre-compressed explosive. The second objective Harts experiments see detonation extinction would occur LX-17. Jack Rabbit provided wealth data validating reactive burn models. Many use pressure-dependent reaction rates require additional modifications model complex shock phenomena. CREST9 based analysis inmaterial gauge data10 concluded first order reaction rate dependent shock strength. CREST depicts shock strength using function entropy non-reacted explosive.11 No additional modifications made model shock desensitization. The conventional explanation shock desensitization weak shock compresses potential hot-spot sites e.g. pores subsequent stronger shocksdetonation waves travelling material deprived reaction sites. This allows CREST simulate complex shock detonation phenomena detonation extinction seen Jack Rabbit without requiring desensitization modification. A rst-principles investigation equation states molecular weak spots -cyclotetramethylene tetranitramine HMX Qing Peng Suvranu De Department Mechanical Aerospace Nuclear Engineering Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute Troy NY 12180 U.S.A. Abstract. We investigate equation states -polymorph cyclotetramethylene tetranitramine HMX energetic molecular crystal using DFT-D2 rst-principles calculation based density functional theory DFT van der Waals vdW corrections. The atomic structures equation states hydrostatic compressions studied pressures 100 GPa. We found N-N bonds along minor axis ring sensitive variation pressure indicates potential weak spots atomic level within single molecule -HMX. Our study suggested van der Waals interactions critically important modeling molecular crystal. Cyclotetramethylene-tetranitramine HMX important secondary explosive commonly used polymer-bonded explosives PBX solid rocket propellant. The P 21c monoclinic -phase molecular crystal shown Fig. 1 thermodynamically stable polymorph HMX room temperature highest density important factor detonation velocity. A molecule ring-chain structure -HMX crystal shown Fig. 1 b. Due importance HMX subjected extensive studies experimental 1 2 3 4 5 theoretical 6 7 8 9. The anisotropic deformation HMX molecular crystals determine mechanical work localized form hot spots promote rapid molecular decomposition necessary detonation 10 11. These hot spots general associated defects crystals including voids grain boundaries dislo cations. In general defects could used engineer materials properties performance 12 13 14 15 16 17. In atomistic models defects molecular crystals sustain high pressures. Here dene weak spots region located weak bonds vulnerable pressure strains however well understood. In addition density plays important role equation state describing thermodynamic properties used describe materials continuum level. 9 Despite importance accurate prediction densities energetic materials challenging. 18 19 Although rst-principles calculations based density functional theory DFT provide overall better predictive power force eld models 20 fail predicting densities energetic materials standard approximations partially due poor descriptions dispersion forces molecular crystals. 21 22 7 4 23 There extensive studies improve mod 1148 eling dispersion interactions van der Waals vdW interactions 24. The DFT-D2 method 25 revised version DFT-D1 method 26 considerable improvement predecessor negligible extra computing demands comparing standard DFT calculations. Its application studying structural properties equation state -HMX high pressure needs investigation. Here model -HMX using DFT-D2 method 25 describes van der Waals interactions simple pair-wise force eld. This method chosen result compromise two opposite considerations accuracy feasibility. We investigate equation state -HMX atomic structures high pressures. We found N-N bonds along minor axis N2-N6 N4-N8 bonds Fig. 1 b weakest bonds thus atomic weak spots -HMX molecules. FIRST-PRINCIPLES MODELLING We consider conventional unit cell containing two HMX molecules 56 atoms total periodic boundary conditions depicted Fig. 1. The total energies system forces atom stresses stress-strain relationships HMX desired deformation congurations characterized via rst-principles calculations based density-functional theory DFT. DFT calculations carried Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package VASP 27 28 29 30 based Kohn-Sham Density Functional Theory KS-DFT 31 32 generalized gradient approximations parameterized Perdew Burke Ernzerhof PBE exchange-correlation functions 33 34. The electrons explicitly included calculations 1s1 hydrogen atoms. 2s22p4 electrons carbon atoms 2s22p5 nitrogen atoms 2s22p6 oxygen atoms. The core electrons replaced projector augmented wave PAW pseudo-potential approach35 36. The kinetic-energy cutoff plane-wave basis selected 800 eV study. The calculations performed zero temperature. The criterion stop relaxation electronic degrees freedom set total energy change smaller 0.000001 eV. The optimized atomic geometry achieved min Unit cell Fig. 1 Geometry -HMX The unit cell -HMX containing two HMX molecules ringchain structure. The four carbon atoms yellow four nitrogen atoms forms ring-chain. molecule ring-chain structure -HMX crystal. The molecule center-symmetric. The N1N3 N2-N4 forms major minor axis ring-chain structure respectively. The four carbon atoms coplanar C4-plane. The four nitrogen atoms ring-chain also coplanar N4-plane. The angle C4-plane N4plane 30.3. imizing Hellmann-Feynman forces acting atom maximum forces ions smaller 0.001 eV. The atomic structures deformed undeformed congurations obtained fully relaxing 168-atom-unit cell. The simulation invokes periodic boundary conditions three directions. The irreducible Brillouin Zone sampled 5 3 4 Gammacentered k-mesh. The initial charge densities taken superposition atomic charge densities. In DFT-D2 method25 van der Waals interactions described using pair-wise force eld. Such semi-empirical dispersion potential added conventional Kohn-Sham DFT energy EDFTD2 EDFT Edisp N number atoms. The summations go atoms translations unit cell L l1 l2 l3. The prime indicates L 0 6 j. Cij6 stands dispersion coefcient atom pair ij. rijL distance atom reference cell L 0 atom j cell L. f r damping function whose role scale force eld minimize contributions interactions within typical bonding distances r. Since van der Waals interactions decay quickly power -6 contributions outside certain suitably chosen cutoff radius negligible. The cutoff radius pair interaction study set 30.0 . Abstract. We develop thermodynamically consistent continuum twinslip phase field model study deformation behavior -HMX. The order parameter associated twinning shear. Dislocations twins phase transformations distinguished modeled within crystal plasticity framework. The Landau potential derived finite elastic deformation analysis. The equilibrium response externally stressed -HMX crystal obtained solving coupled continuum momentum equation phase evolution equation using Helmholtz free energy functional consists elastic potential energy local interfacial energy follows CahnHilliard formalism. We study twin nucleation growth three-dimensional sample HMX molecular single crystal. The results shown compare well experimental observations. molecular crystals determines mechanical work localized form hot spots. When crystalline material HMX Octahydro1357-tetranitro-1357-tetrazocine subjected finite strain two major deformation mechanisms accommodate strain Experimental observation conventional mechanisms plastic flow i.e. dislocation slip also operative molecular HMX single crystal.1 Numerical simulations isotropic elastic-plastic model used account deformations.2 However since plastic yielding -HMX anisotropic orientation dependent use inadequate. The anisotropic plastic response HMX molecular crystals studied various phenomenological model plasticity based constitutive models.34 Crystal plasticity model used elsewhere examine collapse pores influence strain localization shock-loaded -HMX single plastic-deformation studied12345 modeling deformation twinning received much less attention. It reported plastic deformation -HMX attributed mechanical twinning slip.6 Therefore crystal level twinslip model must developed account complex physics encountered nonlinear deformation -HMX. In work focus modeling deformation twinning -HMX investigate role sensitivity. twinning 101 plane P21c monoclinic crystal structure.7 Twinning allows low symmetry monoclinic crystal accommodate large strain. We developed thermodynamically consistent continuum twinslip phase field model study deformation behavior -HMX. Phase Field Modeling In phase field model state variable sometimes called order parameter phase field variable introduced reflect continuum measure molecular orderdisorder different phases. The present work deals nonconserved order parameter associated crystal structure e.g. symmetry andor lattice orientation. As crystal deforms loading may shear form twin. A normalized order parameter 01 introduced account twin shear 0 corresponds parent phase 1 twin region 01 twin boundary interface. For simplicity consider secondary phase transformation twinning model. We adopt multiplicative decomposition deformation gradient tensor F plastic part F p stress-free twinning shear Ft elastic part F FeFtF p det Fe 0 det F p 1 det Ft 1 1 F p describes local plastic deformation due plastic slip crystallographic plane preserving crystal lattice orientation. The lattice deformation local rigid body rotation represented Fe . Twinning modeled via stress-free twinning shear. Twinning -HMX goes several stages. Within elastic limit elastic twins form critical stress reached. As load numerous lattice. In Fig. 1 see loading single crystals 011 face results formation twins 010 face not. Further load increases top bottom twin becomes visible thicker loading 011 face however twin bands visible loading 010 face. We see loading 010 face result resolved shear stress twin direction whereas corresponding growth twinning shear strain increasing uniaxial compressive strain results increased thickness twin band upon loading 011 face. HMX low symmetry crystal two possible slip systems 001100 101101 one coincides twin system. Fig. 1. Twinning -HMX upon loading 011 face twinning 010. We compare distribution twin shear contours increasing load top bottom. Fig. 3. Plastic twinning -HMX upon loading In Fig. 4 see plastic behavior HMX highly anisotropic. The 010100 orientation exhibits linear elastic stress-strain response 110001 orientation exhibits observations.6 Fig. 5 shows volumetric response -HMX single crystal loaded 110 face along 001 direction. Notice elastic orientation 010100 shows relatively volume reduction elastic-plastic orientation 011100. This may significant effect activation mechanism -HMX since plastic slip acts shear relaxation mechanism hence less mechanical work available temperature rise leading chemical reaction. For orientations 010100 large shear stress arises steric hindrance may provide much mechanical work increase temperature required initiate chemical decomposition. Further Fig. 6 see 011100 orientation twinslip plane 101101 accommodate large shear strain. In investigation twinslip phase field modeling verify twinslip plane accommodate large shear strain. We observe orientations yield resolved shear stress twinslip plane along twinslip direction predominantly elastic. For elastic orientations large shear stress arises steric may provides much mechanical work increase temperature detonation. The orientations resolved shear stress along twinslip direction exceeds critical resolved shear stress material starts twinslip absorb strain plastic deformation allowing less sensitive less mechanical work available temperature rise. Therefore twinning plastic slip associated greater shear relaxation hence decreased sensitivity. We may conclude deformation twinning essential accurately capture volumetric response -HMX may significant effect activation. Investigating Shock Initiation Detonation Powder HMX Reactive Mesoscale Simulations H. Keo Springer K. S. Vandersall C. M. Tarver P. C. Souers Energetic Materials Center Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Livermore CA 94550 Abstract. We perform reactive mesoscale simulations study influence material density chemical kinetics energetic grain shape product equation-of-state shock initiation steady-state detonation powder HMX. Model predictions demonstrate good agreement situ pressure gauge data 1.24 gcc HMX0.65 HMX powder subjected input pressure 1.3 GPa. Additional studies reveal run distance shock initiation sensitive slight variations material density chemical kinetics. ALE3D Thermal-Fluids Model An ALE3D thermal-fluids developed model flow thermal species transport along chemical decomposition cookoff. The model composition taken 64 RDX 36 TNT wax neglected. In incompressible flow model single reactant decomposes product species material properties. Gases generated decomposition evaporation assumed move rapidly top HE vessels influence flow decomposition. This relatively simple model allows effects flow mechanics readily investigated. Species Diffusivity Although reactant product species taken identical properties mass diffusivity DAB important two reasons. Abstract. We develop thermodynamically consistent continuum phase field model investigate role deformation driven - phase transition sensitivity RDX. Dislocations phase transformations distinguished modeled within crystal plasticity framework. The Landau potential derived finite elastic deformation analysis. The response externally stressed RDX crystal obtained solving continuum momentum equation along phase evolution equation using Helmholtz free energy functional consists elastic potential energy local interfacial energy follows CahnHilliard formalism. Our simulations suggest - phase transformation RDX may associated increased temperature rise hence sensitivity. The role molecular structure sensitivity energetic materials long established.1 Many factors influence performance energetic materials including sensitivity rate deflagration detonation transition detonation velocity detonation pressure crystal density thermal shock stability ultimately depend polymorphic modifications often ignored.2 The structural change accompanying phase transformation involves increase decrease intermolecular interactions likely serve precondition material onset chemical decomposition higher Understanding predicting effect phase transformations parameters transition detonation high thermomechanical stimuli therefore important challenging problem. At heart need understand complex deformation processes localization energy lead regions material sufficiently high temperature stress conditions promote rapid molecular decomposition. Here model deformation induced - phase transition RDX investigate role sensitivity. compression45 modeling While phase-transformation studies performed RDX cyclo-135-trimethylene246-trinitramine using static3 shock transformation accounts crystal orientation defect evolution received much less attention. RDX known exist polymorphs -phase stable observations establish RDX undergoes - phase transformation pressure range 3.54.5 GPa.3 The - phase transition involves decrease unit cell volume 3 leads changes space group molecular conformations.5 The -RDX orthorhombic structure Pbca space group whereas -RDX orthorhombic structure Pca21 space group. An open question relative sensitivities We developed thermodynamically consistent continuum phase investigate role deformation driven - sensitivity RDX. Dislocations phase transformations distinguished modeled within crystal plasticity framework. The Landau potential derived finite elastic deformation analysis. The response externally stressed RDX crystal obtained solving continuum momentum equation along phase evolution equation using Helmholtz free energy functional consists elastic potential energy local interfacial energy follows Cahn Hilliard formalism.6 In following sections derive phase field model - phase transition RDX. We next present numerical examples discussion followed conclusion. Phase Field Modeling sometimes called We develop thermodynamically consistent transformation molecular single crystal RDX. The single crystal plasticity model extended include phase transformation phenomena using phase field formulation. In phase field model introduced reflect continuum measure molecular orderdisorder different phases. The present work deals non-conserved order associated crystal orientation. We start crystal Phase-I. As deforms loading Phase-I may transform another Phase-II. We introduce normalized order parameter 01 account structural transformation 0 1 denotes Phase-I respectively 01 shear flow expressed boundary. For simplicity consider secondary phase transformation model. We adopt multiplicative decomposition deformation gradient tensor F plastic part F p elastic part Fe F FeF p det Fe 0 det F p 1 F p describes local plastic deformation due plastic slip crystallographic plane preserving crystal lattice orientation. The lattice deformation local rigid body rotation represented Fe . Results Discussion We investigate role deformation driven - phase transition sensitivity RDX using thermomechanical phase field model developed previous section. A finite element computational model developed simulate gas gun tests. The computational model bar dimension 1.00.10.1mm3 discretized using 18000 tri-linear hexahedral finite elements eight Gauss points per element. A time varying pressure load ramped-up zero 5.2GPa pressure 1.0ns applied one faces normal axial direction bar opposite face maintained traction-free. The four faces models normal loading direction constrained onedimensional wave could travel length bar. Artificial viscosity terms included conditioning numerical solution -RDX crystallizes orthorhombic space group Pbca whereas -RDX orthorhombic structure Pca21 space group. Requirements Simulating Transmitted Wave Profile Metal Barriers Leah Tuttle Seth Root Bob Schmitt Eric Harstad Sandia National Lab Abstract. The purpose study examine modeling requirements necessary accurately simulate transmitted wave profile detonating insensitive high explosive IHE metal barriers. The future goal experimental modeling efforts improve understanding ability model gap tests examining transmitted wave seen acceptor explosive. Unlike standard gap tests experimental setup intentionally one-dimensional uniaxial strain. Also unlike standard gap tests first step undertaken study characterize transmitted wave profile. To accomplish task powder gun used launch copper projectile explosive sample. At impact conditions explosive undergoes shock-todetonation transition SDT within sample thickness. The experiment designed allow measurement particle velocities back side explosive sample wave transmitted metal barrier. The data used estimate SDT run distance peak pressure explosive wave structure. The advantages experimental design simplifications experimental measurements simulations. The disadvantages SDT process creates accelerating waves wave profiles require additional modeling fidelity. A reactive flow model required simulate SDT process. It demonstrated reactive flow model must accurately describe evolution initial shock transition detonation propagation remaining explosive thickness. Samples TATB-based explosive LX-17 varying thickness approximately 6.6 8 mm impacted copper flyer 1.25 cm thick 2 kms powder gun experiments conducted Sandia National Laboratories. Two different test configurations used. In first 3 small aluminum copper samples thicknesses 1 2 3 mm bonded via glue layer large disc LX-17. A LiF window bonded metal sample order provide viewing window VISAR1 record particle velocity profiles metalLiF interface. Additionally tests 3 NaCl windows bonded via glue layer microns thickness directly LX-17 explosive sample allow VISAR record particle velocity profile experimental configuration shown Fig. 1. At flyer plate impact conditions explosive undergoes shock-to-detonation transition SDT within sample thickness. The history variable reactive burn HVRB reactive flow model selected first approximation simulate explosive response3. To reproduce structure transmitted wave necessary accurately simulate SDT process post-transition evolution detonation wave. Variations computational results examined variety equations state EOSs HVRB model parameters. These variations used help guide model parameterization. The results simulations compared test results discussion provided limitations current modeling techniques future directions improving explosive model representation experimental design. CTH Model Descriptions CTH Eulerian shock wave physics code. It development continuously Sandia National Laboratories 25 years. CTH includes variety EOSs numerous constitutive models appropriate modeling explosives high-rate mechanical deformation shock-loading conditions. The HVRB model used analysis. The HVRB model comprised three main components unreacted EOS detonation product EOS reaction model mixture assumptions. The reaction model typically calibrated match Pop plot data4. The HVRB model demonstrated simulate SDT process terms run distance. However simplified model accurately reproduce detailed wave evolution occurs SDT measured Gustavsen56. As part study modeling requirements accurately simulate additional aspects The unreacted explosive EOS typically fit shock velocity-particle velocity Us-Up relationship derived wedge tests flyer-plate impact experiments. This experimental data much larger scatter traditional shock Hugoniot data available lower three NaCl windows Fig. 1 The experimental test configuration metalLiF windows top explosive The second test configuration samples tantalum thicknesses 1 2 3 4 mm glued disc LX-17 approximately 8 mm thick also LiF windows providing viewing window VISAR. These tests include NaCl windows explosive interface data wave profile backside explosive The experimental variation flyer impact velocity estimated less 10 ms one four tests conducted. The LX-17 sample thickness measured 17 individual locations location measured 3 times disc explosive total 51 thickness measurements. Variation measurements order 10 m. Neither experimental factors likely significant effect experimental results. Simulations performed one dimension sample copper flyer explosive NaCl stacking using Eulerian shock physics code CTH developed Sandia National Laboratories2. The future goal experimental modeling efforts understanding ability model gap tests examining transmitted wave seen acceptor explosive. Unlike standard gap tests onedimensional uniaxial strain. Also unlike standard gap tests first step undertaken study characterize transmitted wave profile. shock pressures. Reactive flow models require unreacted explosive yields information conditions occurring SDT process detonation wave propagation. These conditions occur much greater pressures typical wedge test impact pressure. The HVRB model CTH typically uses Mie-Gruneisen model describe EOS surface. However complex EOS surfaces represented using Sesame tables. advantage representing In CTH detonation product EOS typically described Sesame table. The Sesame complete EOS surface. Therefore Sesame table used broad range initial explosive densities. Another widely used detonation product EOS Jones-Wilkins-Lee JWL model7. The JWL EOS simple analytic form calibrated isentropic expansion CJ state. The JWL EOS constants valid particular reference density must adjusted changes density detonation velocity. The relevant fits study LX-17 1.9 gcc. The HVRB model specifies reaction completely unreacted completely reacted. The model employs simple mixture rule default requires reactants products density temperature calculate intermediate states needed. The pressurevolume Hugoniots two unreacted two detonation product EOSs shown Fig. 2. As expected unreacted EOSs agree lower pressures diverge higher pressures. Similarly detonation products EOSs agree CJ state vary CJ state. Detonations rate sticks non-ideal explosives propagate speeds signicantly lower one-dimensional Chapman-Jouget CJ detonation velocity. This multi-dimensional effects important class explosives due large reaction zone length behind shock. The one-dimensional model based upon assumption reaction zone thickness much smaller charge width diameter effects negligible. For non-ideal explosives ANFO propagation speed found 50 CJ speed1. Initiation detonation produces shock wave rapidly accelerates explosive reaches steady state propagation velocity D. The shock wave supported exothermic chemical reaction initiated shock propagates explosive. Various steady-state detonation models incorporating two-dimensional effects devel oped. The Wood-Kirkwood model2 considers ow along central axis slightly divergent ow term. This incomplete theory divergent ow term must arbitrarily prescribed often empirically. Another model Detonation Shock Dynamics DSD considers asymptotic limit weak-shock curvature3 shown accurately reproduce shock shapes shape propagating detonation front compared Direct Numerical Simulation DNS experiment. However model assumes detonation speed asymptotically close CJ speed therefore quantitatively predictive highly non-ideal explosives. A novel approach solving non-ideal steady detonations developed. Streamline Approximation SSA assumes streamlines behind shock straight diverging. Previous work shown SSA predicts shock shapes diameter effect detonation velocity versus rate-stick diameter curves accurately compared high resolution Direct Numerical Simulation 4. This would suggest SSA could used predictive tool determining diameter effect curves. To date SSA implemented polytropic equation state simple power law reaction rate. However practical applications modelling real explosives accurately necessary employ sophisticated equation state reaction rate model. To end CREST reactive burn model developed AWE implemented SSA. This paper presents derivation ow equations implementing CREST model Governing Flow Equations Equation It assumed ow described Reactive Euler equations represent conservation mass momentum energy coupled chemical reaction material derivative. Here v material velocity p pressure density e internal energy per unit mass chemical reaction progress variables 0 quiescent material 1 complete reaction W reaction rate typically function thermodynamic variables. Equations 1-4 closed specifying equation state equation governing chemical reaction rate. The CREST model employs two-phase equation state unreacted solid gaseous reaction products present reacting mixture. The solid phase assumed isentrope shocked. Simple mixture laws used calculate specic volume specic internal energy. The solid gaseous phases assumed pressure equilibrium. The relevant equations model E specic internal energy V specic volume P pressure. Subscripts g refer solid gas phases respectively. CREST gives explicit expressions Ps PsVs Es Pg PgVg Eg. Further details equation state model found previously published work 5 6. Given V E point ow equations 6-9 gives four equations four Vs Vg Es Eg unknowns. As equations implicit iterative procedure used solve system point ow. As consequence specic internal energy cannot written analytically function thermodynamic variables. Previous work 4 used explicit analytical equation state i.e. e ep v Euler equations reducing equation velocity coupled reaction rate. With equation state CREST model treatment possible. Muhamed Suceska Chan Hay Yee Serene Ang How-Ghee Nanyang Technological University 50 Nanyang Avenue Block N1-B4a-02 Singapore 639798 Energetics Research Institute Abstract. Due mathematical simplicity ease implementation BeckerKistiakowski-Wilson BKW equation state still used thermochemical computer codes predict detonation parameters despite lack rigorous theoretical background. It gives satisfactory agreement calculated experimentally obtained detonation parameters many standard high explosives densities range 1 1.9 gcm3. However beyond density limits agreement generally poor. A number different parameter sets BKW EOS proposed order overcome limitations shortcomings unfortunately limited success. To address problem applied alternative approach includes optimization covolume factors detonation products obtained ab-initio calculations match experimental shock Hugoniot data adjustments BKW coefficients reproduce experimental detonation pressures velocities also detonation parameters introduction new concept densitypressure-dependent covolume factors well modification BKW EOS adding exponent covolume term x. thermochemical equilibrium code EXPLO5 carried calculations series explosives densities ranging 0.25 1.9 gcm3. The calculation shows palpable improvement accuracy lower densities explosives. The overall error predicting detonation pressure velocity studied explosives expressed root mean square percent error RMS 7.26 2.59 respectively. We found accuracy modified BKW EOS close accuracy physically-based EOS. modified BKW EOS Thermochemical codes use thermodynamics solve simultaneously state variables chemical composition detonation products performance1. One difficult parts accurately describing equations state gases. Various gaseous equations state EOS proposed describe behavior detonation product gases extremely high pressures temperatures. Some Becker-Kistiakowski-Wilson modified Van der Waals EOS3 modified virial Jacobs-Cowperthwaite-Zwisler JCZ EOS5 Exp-6 HMSAMC EOS67 etc. semi-empirical Becker-KistiakowskiWilson BKW EOS one extensively used despite fact rigorous theoretical background. It usually given following form28 p pressure V molar gas volume R gas constant. adjustable parameters xi mole fraction product species ki parameter proportional molecular volume also known covolume factors covolumes Fx imperfection geometrical volume 3 occupied molecule rotating centre mass multiplied factor 10.469.10. As pointed Fried1 term covolume factor somewhat misnomer best treat effective interaction parameter. In high density limits acts effective molecular volume multiplied stiffness factor lower densities related viral coefficients. The present form BKW EOS proposed Cowan Fickett2 1954 since form equation remains unchanged number attempts optimize constants covolumes BKW EOS order parameters. For example Mader10 used two BKW sets parameters BKW-TNT set high carbon explosives BKW-RDX set high oxygen explosives. He used covolumes main detonation products H2O CO2 CO N2 adjusted best reproduce experimental Hugoniot data. Finger et al.11 proposed BKWR set Baer Hobbs12 proposed BKWS parameter set basis large product species calibration. Fried et al.1 employed modern stochastic optimization algorithm parameter set covolumes BKWC set best matched available experimental data. The validity limitation BKW EOS discussed many researchers15121314. They noticed BKW EOS fails reproduce accurately detonation velocities pressures initial densities explosives1214. A fast Fourier transform micromechanical upscaling method study thermal expansion TATB-based pressed explosive Andrey Ambos Herv Trumel Franois Willot Dominique Jeulin Maxime Biessy MINES ParisTech PSL - Research university CMM - Centre mathematical morphology 35 rue St Honor F-77300 FONTAINEBLEAU France CEA DAM Le Ripault F-37260 MONTS France This paper presents rst phase development multiscale numerical method operating microstructureal level TATB-based pressed plastic-bonded explosive. It uses virtual model microstructure mimicking grain size distribution actual material Fourier-based numerical scheme. At present method works simplied microstructure linear anisotropic thermoelastic behavior constituents. Neglecting inter-granular binder leads fairly overestimated values isotropic elastic moduli volumetric coefcient thermal expansion. A rst attempt include binder yielded much realistic predictions elastic moduli volumetric thermal expansion coefcient. The origin discrepancy thought lie behavior constituents. The quasi-static thermo-mechanical behavior TATB-based pressed plastic-bonded explosives complex irreversible highly nonlinear. Progressive damage occurs quasi-static mechanical loading slow thermal loads induce irreversible dilation1 2 often referred ratchet These phenomena still well understood involve necessarily sub-macroscopic processes grain plasticity microcracking debonding. The rst sub-macroscopic level so-called mesoscopic one individual grains micro-cracks grain boundaries become distinct objects remain considered homogeneous objects. This level referred microstructure level sequel roughly optical microscopy. The present work rst step development thermo-mechanical computational method operating microstructural level objective link macroscopic response constituents arrangements behaviors words numerical homogenization Such tool requires geometrical description microstructure ii computational method iii constitutive models constituents As 3D microstructure imaging available date material described method rely virtual models microstructure. The FFT-based upscaling method chosen requires meshing computationally demanding. Finally rst phase development performed framework linear thermoelasticity homogeneous temperature elds slow thermal loads simplied microstructure. The studied material The material considered present work TATB-based pressed plastic-bonded explosive containing less 5 amorphous polymeric binder. The TATB powder rst coated binder slurry process dried granulated yielding 1 mm diameter prills. The latter isostatically pressed 200 MPa moderate The resulting solid material relatively easy polish using standard metallographic-like procedure allows optical microscopy reected polarized light observations3 4 carried Fig. 1. Hooks2 Jaroslaw Majewski3 Saurabh Singh3 1 Shock Detonation Physics Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos NM 87545 Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos NM 87545 2 Weapons Experiments 3 Los Alamos Neutron Science Center LANSCE Lujan Center Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos NM 87545 Abstract. Molecular composites plastic-bonded explosives PBX exhibit complex anisotropic deformation response thermal mechanical stimuli. The anisotropic response driven constituent materials microstructure composite specifically bulk deformation fracture events often influenced mesoscale mechanisms crystal deformation crystal-binder interfacial failure. Here used combination neutron reflectometry ellipsometry measure high precision crystal-binder interfacial chemistry several PBXs interest determining composition function distance crystal binder. Selected PBX materials probed mechanically nanoindentation assess true effect measured interfacial composition structure deformation fracture behavior. For example inclusion plasticizing agent one formulation altered chemical composition interface structure resulted weaker crystal-binder bond. Plastic-bonded explosives PBX complex composites comprised micron-sized energetic crystals polymer matrix. A concept reactive hot spots intruded base structural reactive material SRM casing investigated generate fine primary secondary fragments efficient energy release thick casing material explosive loading. This achieved distributing micro-scale reactive material particles base SRM fuel-rich equivalence ratio. Reaction particles SRM primary secondary fragmentation creates heat gas products form micro-scale hot spots whose expansion initiates local fractures leading fine SRM fragments. Test casings 7.62 cm inner diameter made using micro-scale Al-CuO hot spot material distributed base Al cold gas dynamic spray deposition technology reached yield stress 200 MPa. Explosion experiments conducted 3 diameter 23 m3 cylindrical chamber cased charges casing-to-explosive mass ratio 1.76. The results demonstrated efficient fragment combustion leading 50 increase blast front pressure early time 17 increase quasi-static pressure late times versus pure Al-cased charges thus indicating feasibility concept. A structural reactive material SRM defined possess high energy material density well structural strength. Often SRM metallurgically made grain-scale reactive metals metal-oxides sometimes inert metal additives SRM bears bulk meso-scale properties. As SRM-cased explosive charge detonates casing fragmentation deliver high speed fragments Combustion reactive fragments effectively contribute air blast depending reaction mechanism fragment material also sizes concentration fragments. One key parameters SRM-cased explosive charge mass ratio casing explosive MC.2 For continuum aluminum Al casing free-field blast enhancement reported mostly thin casings small MC values resulted fine fragments combust. Little augmentation air blast observed free field thick Al casings MC 1.75 majority primary fragments relatively large thus function inert material. Blast enhancement thick casings observed confined environments fragment impact targets whereby generated combustion. Additional mechanisms therefore desired order create primary secondary fine fragments efficient energy release large MC casings. One sub-fragmentation mechanisms uses impedance mismatch within SRM microscale multiple ingredients.34 In small-scale tests3 cold iso-statically pressed rings 4-30 AlTungsten granular composite provided fragment sizes order hundred micrometers explosive loading. This attributed large velocity gradients developed impedance materials structure discontinuities. Using 3.5 kg thick casing NiAl laminate composite 50-150 layer thickness4 explosive loading depicted significantly enhanced blast front pressures near-field. In case shock dynamics interfaces different impedance ingredients resulted nonuniform high local temperatures stresses late times dissimilar inertia led different accelerations. Sub-fragmentation depends meso-scale structure dissimilar ingredients. In present work another mechanism studied using micro-scale reactive hot spots intruded base SRM casing initiate local fractures leading fine SRM fragments. Theoretical Consideration In order generate fine primary secondary fragments increase energy release efficiency thick SRM casing explosive loading concept hot spots within base SRM considered. This could achieved distributing micro-scale reactive material particles base SRM fuel rich equivalence ratio. During casing fragmentation upon charge detonation impact primary fragments target reaction particles would create heat gas products form micro-scale hot spots whose expansion initiates local failure fractures leading fine SRM fragments. Due fuel rich ratio SRM added hot spot material produced fine fragments would mostly original SRM rapidly combust air provide energy output. Al Copper oxide CuO particles chosen interposed base Al due reaction heat amount high temperature gas products O O2 AlO Al2O etc. Assuming reaction Al-CuO dominated diffusion local reactions around distributed particles would near stoichiometric atomic ratio NAlNCuO 23 resulting heat reaction 4.077 kJg. The equilibrium explosion temperature estimated 4640 K constant volume theoretical material density TMD phase changes. In previous work5 diffusiondominated reaction reported responsible combustion propagation cold-sprayed AlCuO composite density approached TMD. Numerical simulations performed examine concept feasibility. A 1.25 x 0.5 mm planar 2D slab model used represent hot spots base material. Hot spots modeled ellipses 50 x 100 dimension filled stoichiometric Al-CuO. The spacing hot spots filled Al set target volume fraction 0.331 coincide overall fuel-rich atomic ratio NAlNCuO 2.5. The mesh Cartesian containing uniform square cells 0.5 size. The solid materials Al-CuO C4 explosive represented using Mie-Grneisen equation state parameters thermophysical states respective shock Hugoniots. The products hot spot combustion modeled using JWL equation state expansion fitting Cheetah code. An Eulerian multi-material numerical equilibrium mixed states. The hydrodynamic response include strength effects since pressure exceeded material yield strength order magnitude. If hot spot particles react immediately upon detonation shock entering casing impacting expansion hot spots would slow due resistance highly shocked pressures surrounding base Al. A reaction delay hot spot particles may therefore preferred allow sufficient decay shocked pressures base Al. Thus reaction hot spot particles assumed reasonable delay casing expanded near failure 50100 typical Al casings right primary fragmentation whereby pressure approaches ambient. Ignition temperature another key parameter hot spot material reaction. In recent vacuum experimental study6 ignition temperatures found similar arrest-reactive-milled nanocomposites 2Al3CuO 4AlFe2O3 8AlMoO3 2.35AlBi2O3 range 800950 K around Al melting point. The study also indicated likelihood low-temperature redox reactions occurring prior ignition prone rapid decomposition upon heating. Experimental Procedures In order make metastable interstitial composite satisfies SRM definition cold gas dynamic spray deposition technology employed using high purity aluminum copper oxide powders. The average particle sizes d50Al 27 d50CuO 4 m. The mixture mechanically premixed following required fuel rich equivalence ratio. The powder mixture sprayed 6061 Al substrate tube 7.6 cm external diameter using commercial EP-system Centerline Ltd Windsor pressurized helium gas heated 12kW gas heater flowed nozzle generating supersonic flow powder injected right nozzle throat. Upon impact substrate particles built deposit intense local plastic deformation solid state without reaction. This produced SRM satisfied mechanical strength high TMD little volumetric porosity examined using scanning electronic microscopy SEM depicted Fig. 4. The cold spray system equipped plastic nozzle allowing gas temperature Fig. 4. SEM image cold-sprayed 6AlCuO Al indicated dark grey color. Fig. 5. A cold-sprayed 6AlCuO thick casing. The casing microstructure analysis made sample cross-sections using optical microscopy SEM. The proportions CuO inside SRM cylinder 18 vol corresponding atomic ratio close NAlNCuO 6 weight ratio 6733 wt. The image analysis polished cross section views revealed porosity content less 0.5 consistent measured SRM density 3.22 gcm3. Although porosity content small collapse related voids enhance local temperature favor initiating Al-CuO reaction explosive loading. The SRM exhibited yield stress 190-220 MPa elastic modulus 463 GPa obtained flexural stress-strain line strain range 0 0.35 using four-point bending Vickers microhardness measured cross-sections along coating thickness average hardness 965. The measured safety data SRM sample BAM Fall Hammer Impact 50 J BAM Friction 360 N Electrostatic Discharge ESD 2008A 10 J compared 3 J 60 N 0.16 J PETN respectively. Differential scanning calorimetry tests 5Cmin 50mLmin N2 showed exotherms present 40C 600C. Two configurations fuel-rich thick casings 7.62 cm inner diameter made 1 premixed 6AlCuO casing 2 pure Al 5Al3CuO alternatively layered casing. The premixed casings reached yield stress 200 MPa. Henric stmark henric.oestmarkfoi.se Andreas Helte Swedish Defence Research Agency FOI SE-164 90 Stockholm Sweden Abstract. A series experiments conducted order evaluate potential melt-cast ADNAl high-performance underwater explosive. A method melt casting ADN ADNAl 20 kg scale developed. By adding 1 MgO kernel starters densities range 92 99 TMD reached. The charges tested underwater test facility bubble shock wave energies measured. The result total energy 2.4 times TNT 1.26 times In modern warfare need powerful underwater explosives identified number applications. Our existing weapons systems need lethal due emerging harder kill threats. More powerful explosives also needed order reduce size weapons systems e.g. torpedoes. Ammonium dinitramide ADN high explosive powerful oxidizer potential replacement ammonium perchlorate AP propellants underwater explosives 1-3. Mixed aluminum powder potential high performing underwater explosive. In Sweden UK explosives identified promising candidate respect performance. ADNAl charges melt casted using special techniques. To evaluate underwater performance number different compositions ADNAl containing varying degree type aluminum manufactured fired Swedish outdoor underwater lvsnabben UK test site WesternSuper-Mare. Numerical simulations used assess vulnerability naval platforms subjected underwater explosions effectiveness weapon systems containing high-explosives proper description HE available. A JWL equation state EOS determined one tested compositions cylinder test data. Hydrocode simulations propagation bubble dynamics using EOS showed excellent agreement experiments. The results underwater tests show ADNAl underwater explosives outperform bubble energy without sacrificing shock energies. indicate varying particle size mass fraction aluminum bubble energy shock aluminum content size aluminum particles possible increase shock energy bubble energy. The main tailored. By optimizing remains open question sensitivity reduced acceptable level. Melt Casting Technique ADN melt cast easily technique melt casting TNT cannot directly applied1. MgO effective stabilizer ADN also works nucleate crystal kernels within Unstabilized ADN cannot melt cast due excessive gas generation rate risk initiation. ADN must also contain moisture make melt-castable mechanically stable. Aluminum powder mixed ADN least 35 wt content without problems. In fact Al mixtures easier cast ADN without Al correct type aluminum powder. The optimal aluminum powder particle size 10 spherical smooth particles 50 irregularly shaped powder. ADN significantly better mechanical properties pure ADN. ADN aluminum produces better quality casting compared pure ADN i.e. relative density percentage TMD higher aluminized ADN. Aluminum particles functions crystallizing kernels ADN producing much finer crystalline material solidifying making difficult obtain tension-free casting. An embedded heater middle cast form customary casting TNT cannot used. Instead forms heated externally solidification take place axially. The highest density cast ADN ADNAl obtained material solidified axial front fast possible starting bottom low coefficient conductivity limits size charges cast due gas evolution melted substance. Charges 100 mm diameter 300 mm length successfully cast hence maximum dimensions cast ADN charge By adding 1 MgO formulation small scale ADNAl charges casted successfully densities range 92-99 . It proved difficult attain high densities large scale charges 5-20 kg. All charges tested produced work contains around 1 MgO stabilizer nucleation kernel. A extensive description melt cast technique found paper Hahma4. Underwater performance tests The experimental set-up used experiments normally used Sweden underwater performance tests shown Figure 1. The test-area east coast Sweden Baltic Sea see Figure 2. The water depth test area approximately 42 meters. The primary diagnostic consists four tourmaline pressure transducers different distances charge approximately 3.90 7.00 12.50 23.00 exact distances measured shot. Evaluation UW explosives performance characterized two performance parameters specific shockwave energy specific bubble energy. The pressure pulse shock wave generated underwater explosive sharp followed approximately exponential decrease characterised peak pressure Pm time constant The exponential decay general valid one following pressure pulse decreases slowly sometimes also contains bumps. An approximate formula shock wave energy flux density account finite amplitude after-flow effects expressed solely terms pressure given The specific shockwave energy es obtained integrating energy flux density spherical surface radius R divide expression charge weight Q. limit T energy integral set 5 charges detonated Sweden 6.7 charges detonated UK. The bubble energy defined work done expanding bubble maximal volume expressed terms maximum bubble radius. Since maximum bubble radius measured directly instead used approximate method makes use bubble period i.e. time shockwave first bubble collapse. In work used analytic expression Swisdak5 giving bubble period constant kb terms bubble period charge weight charge depth total water depth hydrostatic pressure.
