Clark Souers Energetic Materials Center Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Livermore CA 94550 USA Abstract. LLM-105 26-diamino-35-dinitropyrazine-1-oxide insensitive high explosive performance HMX TATB. It insensitive shock spark friction impact insensitivity level approaching TATB. These properties make realistic high-performance insensitive high explosive material attractive applications require moderate performance insensitivity. Several LLM-105 morphologies plastic-bonded formulations prepared detonation performance experimentally studied. We present chemistry based modeling formulations experiments using thermochemical code CHEETAH linked multi-dimensional ALE hydrodynamics model. Using CHEETAH explicitly specify explosive material composition initial density. We show CHEETAH able accurately model different LLM-105 based explosives formulations wide range densities using burn rate model. LLM-105 26-diamino-35-dinitropyrazine-1oxide newly developed insensitive high explosive IHE. It excellent thermal stability cold-performance effects performance HMX TATB1. Its calculated energy content 85 HMX 15 TATB. It insensitive shock spark friction impact insensitivity level approaching TATB. These combined properties make realistic high-performance IHE material attractive applications require moderate performance insensitivity. Several LLM-105 morphologies plasticbonded formulations prepared range densities performance experimentally studied. The rate development formulations limited synthesis considerations. The synthesis route used dimethoxy pyrazine DMP starting reagent. This route refined increase yields reduce impurities reduce costs. The DMP route produces high quality crystals modest 40-50 um mean size. However route also yields 5-10 ANPZ 26diamino-35-dinitropyrazine co-product lower density 1.800 gcc less energy LLM-105. A second route developed recently uses significantly less expensive starting reagents produce stable intermediate DAPO 26-diamino-pyrazine-1-oxide.2 This intermediate non-explosive manufactured quantity nitrated single step separate controlled process. This results safer less costly manufacturing path. The new synthesis yields pure product good yield. However new route yields smaller 20 um crystals resulting challenging formulation part fabrication issues. The changing synthesis manufacturing paths led variety research formulations developed LLNL. Most formulations PBXs - plastic bonded explosives. PBXs molding powders compacted high loads 20-30 kpsi shape part machined desired shape. The detonation performance PBX heavily dependent upon density quality compaction defined porosity uniformity porosity. Furthermore compaction process highly dependent upon size shape formulations attempted balance energy content compaction qualities varying type amount binder. Viton-A DuPont Kel-F 800 historically used PBX9502 FK-800 manufactured 3M closely resemble Kel-F 800 binders used study. Increased binder content generally help improve compaction results part lower density energy content. A second method achieving better compaction use combination coarse fine explosive crystals. The fine crystals made milling process either fluid energy milling ball milling combined particles 13 ratio. This bimodal distribution particle size usually results compacted part 1-2 higher density mono-modal formulation. Table 1 shows composition synthesis route particle description used formulation discussed paper. We present chemistry based modeling wall foil velocity experiments LLM-105 base explosives using thermochemical code CHEETAH33-4 linked multi-dimensional ALE hydrodynamics model. CHEETAH multi-phase first principle based equation state model uses starting point gas phase model based exponential-6 potential. Condensed phases treated extended Murnaghan equation state. The linked CHEETAH-ALE model treats slowly reacting chemical species using kinetic rate laws chemical equilibrium assumed species coupled via fast time scale reactions. simultaneously treated. This results flexible self-consistent treatment equation state concentrations condensed gaseous species significant variations The CHEETAH model developed treat different LLM-105 based explosives simply specifying chemical composition initial explosive density. Differing binder materials Viton Kel-F binder concentrations considered. The differences variants Viton Kel-F ignored since binder concentration per cent total explosive mass. Aluminum often included additive chlorate-based formulation another fuel present rather lone fuel combination potassium chlorate KC another oxidizer.1 Aluminized explosives typically non-ideal long sequential reaction zones depend particle size factors explosives pressures brisance higher overall blast potential due later time combustive effects. As electropositive metallic elements aluminum oxidation strongly exothermic. In case KC aluminum balanced reaction assuming full conversion aluminum-to-aluminum oxide Al2O3 follows KClO3 2 Al KCl Al2O3 Aluminum present explosive formulation may may participate fully detonation explosive. Even fully converted aluminum oxide rate reaction may aluminum contributes primarily late-time afterburn little blast properties formulation. The aluminum may also form Al2O3 reactions water carbon dioxide formed reaction KC another fuel present rather via direct reaction KC. Kinetic Plate Experiment Design Much work done measuring equations state EOS various types explosives remains unclear whether EOS contains sufficient information predict performance types explosive material blast delivered non-ideal explosives may couple efficiently structures concern. In attempt understand differences blast effects different explosive charges kinetic plate test developed.2 Similar ballistic pendulum3 test allows integrated measurement detonation energy early blast performance momentum transfer. The experiment uses laser velocimetry measure momentum delivered test structures. The basic test setup shown Figure 3. The technique used 12.7 cm 5 inch square 1.3 cm thick steel plate weighing 1.6 kilograms 0.95 cm 38 inch thick steel collar prevent blast waves passing around plate within experimental time scale. The plate collar placed 15.2 cm 6 inches center explosive charge. Test geometry chosen present surface facing explosive charge within fireball generated detonation charge appropriate many relevant applications. The plate thickness mass result velocities fast available instrumentation slow enough plate distortion would change significantly experimental time scales. measured accurately Fig. 3. Kinetic plate experimental setup. The square plate loosely taped inside outer collar tolerances gap plates small possible without inhibiting plate motion. The strip tape stabilized hardware prior detonation unlikely impose significant resistance inter-plate motion normal plate surface. There likewise significant resistance collar rotation relative base. High-speed video demonstrated plate velocities slightly faster collar intended. The primary diagnostic employed test series Photonic Doppler Velocimetry PDV laser interferometric technique utilized 1550 nm infrared laser light measure plate velocity first 300-400 motion. Four PDV probes three uniquely define movement plate one redundant probe mounted aluminum plate square array. The laser probes mounted opposite explosive charge distance 10.2 15.2 cm 4 6 inches plate aligned perpendicular plate surface using mirror prior detonation. The KCfuel explosive charges formed using hemispherical mold. The booster placed center charge RP-1 detonator positioned parallel plate. The setup lined tape hold together keep spherical shape. Barometric Calorimeter Experiment Design After detonation many explosives release additional energy detonation products mix thermo-chemically react ambient environment. This additional afterburn energy combustion detonation products ambient oxygen. While detonation energy release occurs time scale microseconds afterburn energy release occurs time scale milliseconds time varying energy release rate dependent upon local temperature pressure. Barometric calorimeter experiments executed nitrogen characteristics afterburn KCfuel explosives without aluminum additive. These tests provide pressure time histories along theoretical analytical solutions offer engineering basis differentiating timeevolving role explosives without Experiments performed 506-liter barometric calorimeter rated charges 147 gram TNT equivalent. The 506-liter calorimeter cylindrical vessel inner diameter 86.4 cm 34 inches height 86.4 cm. The circular lid 17 available ports pressure gauges diagnostics. Figure 4 shows lid large calorimeter lowered onto base. Suspended spherical charges employed KCfuelAl mixtures. The test configuration uses spherical PBX N5 booster integrated RP 3 detonator. The detonatorbooster assembly placed center spherical shell subsequently filled test explosive sealed. The charge volume held constant tests. Temporally spatially resolved measurements temperature field inside expanding post-detonation fireball interest energetic materials community. Fireball opacity limits optical diagnostic measurements fireball surface destructive high temperatures pressures produced render contact measurement methods unreliable. Moreover contact methods typically lag response extremely fast dynamics detonation event. A new approach probe interior fireball seed thermal sensing nano- micron-sized particles explosive event. These materials undergo physical chemical changes due thermal exposure. Analysis recovered samples used find peak temperatures sensed particles. An important characteristic small particles like fast response changes temperature surroundings compared thermocouples. One relevant application interior fireball temperatures desired development energetic materials use biological weapons. The exposure history bacterial spore inside fireball must known order measure model biocidal efficacy. Picatinny NJ USA Abstract. A series rapid combustion experiments reported provide evidence support multiple reaction pathways porous siliconsodium perchlorate system. These experiments designed isolate effects various energy transport mechanisms. By separating two strips porous silicon energetic material convective energy transfer mode observed deterring convective mode indicated reaction could still propagate rapidly unsteady jump events observed. These unsteady propagation jumps attributed shock waves traveling test substrates carry enough energy initiate combustion downstream. This rapidly reacting porous silicon provides energy rate capable igniting primary energetic materials could used future fuzing applications. On-chip energetic porous silicon offers many requirements lithographically defined precision micrometer scale features use microgram quantities lead-free reactants forming potent pyrotechnic energetic material. Several studies performed quantitatively analyze porous silicon combustion 1 6 10 11. From studies porous silicon shown wide range combustion performance on-chip burn speeds ranging 1 3600 ms 9 11. The high end range allows rapid energy release potential use fuzing due part likely presence multiple combustion mechanisms much still unknown controlling parameters porous silicon combustion particularly burn rates 1500 ms. A better understanding mechanisms contribute significantly use applications well promising areas micro-propulsion. Rapid flame propagation porous silicon often accompanied observed phenomena unsteady flame propagation events demonstrated moderate rapid flame speeds 7 11. For moderate speeds 200 ms Plummer et al. hypothesized lift-off porous silicon film results confinement hot product gases escape weak points along porous silicon film 11. For rapid combustion 1500 ms suggested flame jumps may caused acoustic shock events traveling porous silicon film ahead main reaction front acoustic velocity affecting weak points film triggering combustion event upstream propagation 9. In study compared flame jumps speed sound various porous silicon films. However evidence shock acoustic waves causing flame jumps would solidify hypothesis. reaction mechanism previously demonstrated flame speeds exceeding 3 kms appears complex. Typically rapid burning solid propellants convective heat thought major contributor reaction process 3 5 12 15. However phenomena jumping events described difficult explain convective combustion mechanism could due shock within porous silicon film. The speed sound silicon 8500 ms speed sound porous silicon varies porosity 4. Fan et al measured speed sound porous silicon low 700 ms 84 high porosity films 3000 ms lower porosity films 57. Given characteristic acoustic impedance bulk single crystal silicon nearly 10X porous silicon reasonable expect acoustic waves porous silicon film confined film. Given speed sound porous silicon close observed flame speeds detonation deflagration detonation transition considered. The jump events observed could indicative In study present evidence acoustic shock initiation rapid combustion porous silicon. We note use term acoustic shock differs conventional use shock context detonation. We performed several experiments investigate previously described flame provide evidence effect due acoustic shock event rather convectively controlled mechanism. detonating systems observed confined environment unconfined combustion system may deflagration detonation transition without achieving full detonation front. Low-Energy Laser Initiation Explosives The last two decades seen development laser-initiated detonators purpose seeking higher margins safety detonators used weapon systems test-firing operations. Towards end significant development new high-power detonators using non-electrical source short duration high-peak-power laser pulse. These laser detonators use lowefficiency pulsed lasers usually employ Qswitching pulse durations nanosecond regime. This paper examines low-average power laser detonator using highly efficient thermal initiation mechanism reduce need high peak q-switched accompanying low electrical efficiency. These systems low-average energy systems tens watts milliseconds highly efficient diode lasers low-energy optically initiated detonators providing advantage efficient diode laser source low susceptibility electrostatic electromagnetic damage. Over 30 issues identified indicate standard test methods may require modification applied HMEs derive accurate sensitivity assessments.34 The recommendations modification testing 1 develop new sampling methods guarantee obtaining representative sample particularly small samples mixtures samples volatile component samples large mismatch particle sizes 2 carefully assess particle-size distributions mixtures particle size affects measurements 3 recognize safety testing linked handling conditions safety testing conditions must reflect operation assessed 4 recognize relative sensitivity standard change testing conditions altered testing may reflect true sensitivity material specific application 5 develop new methods test liquids specifically handling volatility issue standards 6 develop instrument-based detection lessen reliance observation. inter- intra-laboratory testing. Synthesis Thermal Stability Novel Explosive Materials BNFF BNFF-1 ANFF-1 Roman Tsyshevsky1 Philip Pagoria2 Maija M. Kuklja1 1 Materials Science Engineering Department University Maryland College Park MD 20742 2 Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory 7000 East Street Livermore CA 94550 Abstract. We report synthesis modeling new energetic compounds 34-Bis4nitro-125-oxadiazol-3-yl-125-oxadiazole-1-oxide 34-bis4-nitro-125oxadiazol-3-yl-125-oxadiazole BNFF-1 3-4-amino-125-oxadiazol-3-yl-4-4nitro-125-oxadiazol-3-yl-125-oxadiazole ANFF-1. Density functional theory based calculations used refine molecular structure novel compounds. Modeling activation barriers reaction rate constants main decomposition channels gas phase indicates new materials likely relatively low sensitivity initiation detonation. However thermal stability decomposition scenarios differ traditional nitro-arenes. Nitro-substituted multi-cyclic heterocyles 34-Bis4-nitro-125-oxadiazol-3-yl125-oxadiazole-2-oxide DNTF BNFF first reported 200212 interest next generation energetic compounds. Their good thermal stability low melting point 110 C sensitivity make multi-cyclic heterocycles Figure 1 attractive candidate materials use secondary explosives34567891011 oxidizers rocket propellant formulations7 possibly melt-castable explosive detonator materials12. properties BNFF reasoned furazan analog 34-Bis4-nitro-125-oxadiazol-3yl-125-oxadiazole BNFF-1 would also interesting target molecule. Indeed BNFF-1 melting point 85 C DSC exotherm peak Intriguingly 3-4-amino-125oxadiazol-3-yl-4-4-nitro-125-oxadiazol-3-yl125-oxadiazole ANFF-1 also fairly low melting point 100 C despite possibility increased intermolecular hydrogen bonding. Their low melting temperatures coupled good stability melt make materials attractive melt-castable explosives. In article aimed analyzing structure bond strengths new molecules present synthesis procedure combined theoretical modeling channels BNFF-1 ANFF-1 gas-phase molecules. We compare reactivity BNFF-1 ANFF-1 various known explosive compounds terms calculated Arrhenius parameters available experimental data. Computational details Decomposition reactions gas-phase studied within density functional theory DFT GGA-PBE M06 GAUSSIAN code13. All molecular calculations performed using double-zeta cc-pVDZ basis set. surface calculations performed GGA approximation PBE exchange correlation functional PAW pseudo-potentials implemented plane wave VASP code141516. In simulating ideal BNFF crystal used 322 MonkhorstPack kpoint mesh kinetic energy cut-off set 800 eV. Atomic coordinates constants allowed simultaneously relax convergence criterion electronic steps set 10-4 eV maximum force acting atom set exceed 0.02 eV. Surface reactions simulated slab model supercell consisted three-molecule-thick surface layer cut create 001 surfaces. A vacuum layer 10 large size supercell ensured spurious interactions products neighbor cells minimal. Surface supercell calculations performed Gamma point kinetic energy cut-off set 600 eV. The convergence criteria electronic ionic steps set 10-4 eV 0.03 eV Minimal energy paths VASP periodic calculations obtained nudged elastic band method six intermediate images. Atomic positions relaxed using conjugate gradient quasi-Newtonian methods within force tolerance 0.05 eV. Reaction rates calculated applying transition state theory TST reactions well-defined transition states variational TST reactions barriers described BNFF. BNFF-1. Procedure 1 Into 1 Liter 3-necked thermometer stir bar addition funnel placed trifluoroacetic acid 350 mL 34-Bis4amino-125-oxadiazol-3-yl-125-oxadiazole 10g 0.04 mol. With stirring solution cooled 20 C ice bath 70 hydrogen peroxide 35 mL 19.5g 0.57 mol added dropwise. Little exotherm occurs upon addition. The mixture allowed warm room temperature stir overnight. Upon warming mixture turns blue-green color. After 5 hours clear yellow solution forms although cases small amount yellow precipitate present. The yellow precipitate removed filtration glass fiber filter paper flask containing ice water 1.1 L stirred one hour. Initially milky white suspension forms BNFF-1 slowly solidifies upon stirring. The solid collected suction filtration washed water allowed suction dry yield light yellow powder 8.3g 67. The calculated activation barriers reaction rates pre-exponential factors collected Table 1. The Arrhenius parameters Table 1 reaction rates Fig. 3 revealed cleavage central ring dominates decomposition initiation BNFF-1 ANFF-1 molecules breaking peripheral rings requires slightly higher energy. In contrast BNFF-1 ANFF-1 cleavage outer ring dominates BNFF decomposition. Most importantly concerted ring opening reactions exhibit lowest activation barriers 47-50 kcalmol Table 1 among mechanisms explored three The next important decomposition mechanism homolytic C-NO2 bond cleavage usually considered primary decomposition reaction step nitro-compounds. Despite fastest reaction C-NO2 homolysis prevails high temperatures due notably higher activation barrier 60 kcalmol Table 1 ring opening process. The CONO isomerization could co-exist primary dissociation channel although somewhat higher activation barrier ring opening reactions. However CONO reaction proceeds much lower rate Fig. 3 due noticeably low pre-exponential factor. Table 1. Table 2 shows break C-NO2 bond BNFF molecule placed surface costs 56.2 kcalmol 3.6 kcalmol lower gas-phase. Reaction rates decomposition channels 001 BNFF surface We report preliminary study synthesis stability novel energetic furazan-based heterocycles. Calculated Arrhenius parameters revealed cleavage furazan ring dominates thermal decomposition BNFF BNFF-1 ANFF-1 molecules. The next important decomposition mechanism homolytic C-NO2 bond cleavage. Despite fastest reaction C-NO2 homolysis prevails high temperatures. Solid-state periodic calculations BNFF showed surface decomposition proceeds similarly molecular decomposition. Our calculations imply initiation chemistry novel explosives notably different typical nitramines e.g. HMX RDX nitro-arenes e.g. TATB. On one hand NO2 homolysis relatively high activation barrier comparable nitro-arenes 60 kcalml. On hand heterocyclic ring opening mechanism activated lower energy 45 kcalmol likely favorable decomposition pathway BNFF BNFF-1 ANFF-1 materials. Any conclusions recommendations expressed material authors necessarily represent views The Effect Confinement Cookoff Plastic Bonded Explosive PBX 9501 Michael L. Hobbs Michael J. Kaneshige Engineering Sciences Center Sandia National Laboratories Albuquerque NM 87185 Energetics Components Center Sandia National Laboratories Albuquerque NM 87185 Abstract. The apparent random response cookoff explosives exposed accidental fire resulting loss life property remains major unsolved problem. Even well controlled laboratory cookoff experiments Sandias Instrumented Thermal Ignition SITI experiment occasionally anomalous results. We propose anomalous results explained pressure-dependent reactions occur within explosives pressed close theoretical maximum density TMD. We postulate self-confinement effects enhanced gas-phase reactions rate limiting gases retained within energetic material. This condition occurs high-density pressings especially binder used melt-castable explosive little internal porosity. We show experimental modeling evidence supporting hypothesis using plastic bonded explosive PBX 9501. The need understand cookoff explosives magnified USS Forestall aircraft carrier severely damaged accidental jet fuel fire series explosions killed 134 men injured 161 men caused 72 million damage 1967.1 Knowing ignition time amount decomposition gases burn behavior damaged energetic materials EM minimize losses. Small-scale experiments like one-dimensional time-to-ignition ODTX experiment2 Sandias instrumented thermal ignition SITI experiment3 used study cookoff. Unfortunately small-scale experiments always scale larger systems. Decomposing explosives generate gas pressures high 1500 atm 22000 psi ODTX experiment confinement failure. This pressure significantly higher expected bursting pressure larger systems especially failure occurs welded experiment significantly higher pressures fast lower pressure system. kinetics obtained rate-limiting step The pressure generated SITI experiment represents gas pressure accessible gaugethat gases escaped bulk explosive. The gas pressure produced decomposition deep within pores explosive may significantly higher measured pressure. For highly pressed explosive little porosity pressure generated In current work pressure dependency also thought dominating gas phase reaction since gas concentration directly proportional pressure e.g. nV PRT. closed-pore network. The pressure generated within closed-pore networks dominate reaction process. Behrens discussed ratecontrolling microscopic defects crystalline HMX.4 Behrens reaction scheme depended 9 different physical processes. Incorporating morphological features model large-scale systems Recently incorporated engineering model thermally decomposing PBX 9502.5 This model used successfully simulate vented sealed systems containing 2 1300 g PBX 9502 95 TATB 5 Kel-F.6 reaction describes The objective current paper apply principles closed-pore decomposition cookoff PBX 9501 95 HMX 2.5 Estane 2.5 BDNPA-F. Four reaction steps used model PBX 9501 ignition. The first reaction describes drying removal adsorbed water PBX nonvolatile residue NVR stable water decomposition NVR stable equilibrium reaction describes decomposition PBX equilibrium products. Only last reaction assumed pressure dependent. The remainder paper describes model predictions ODTX SITI experiments. We model thermal ignition PBX 9501 solving conductive energy equation using volumetric source chemical reactions. Two reactions use distributed activation energies one reactions uses pressure-dependent reaction rate. The pressure assumed function time PxyztPt. However pressure calculated within closed pore volume sealed systems. The closed pore volume increases due thermal expansion bulk explosive due strain caused gas generation. We use empirical strain model engineering simplification complex stress strain constitutive model7 beyond scope current work. The current model assumes single temperature gas condensed phases Tgxyzt Tcxyzt. The model also assumes pore space either fully open fully closed. Summary Conclusions Ignition PBX 9501 modeled using data based observations various confined one vented experiment. This pressure-dependent confinement venting least single vented experiment. The model also evaluated using data laboratories1 ODTX experiments 2 g PBX 9501 2 verification experiment using 70 g PBX 9501 Naval Air Warfare Center. The model adequately predicted experiments performed different scales. We believe additional experiments necessary improve model better understand effect venting. We suggest obtaining data vented experiments well investigate effects density since experiments performed single density. The PBX 9501 model discussed current work preliminary model. We believe model improved significantly using unconfined SITI experiments similar done Reference 5. Maienschein Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Abstract. The LLNL-scaled thermal explosion experiment STEX designed numerous diagnostics order 1 capture physics chemistry explosive prior thermal ignition 2 quantitatively measure violence post-ignition. With abundance diagnostics supporting experiments decomposition kinetics deflagration rates mechanisms thermal explosion better understood. Here discuss recent experiments Comp-B emphasis importance vessel confinement strength inclusion vent hole vessel. Our discussion highlight pre-ignition mechanisms provide insight mechanisms dictate violence Comp-B possibly explosives. chemical physical mechanisms underlying thermal explosion energetic material assessment accident prevention. These mechanisms complex therefore experiments modelingsimulations need complement other. At Lawrence Livermore National Lab LLNL approach parameterize models small experiments e.g. 10g validate models medium scale experiments e.g. 1000g predict thermal explosions using models. To end Scaled Thermal Explosion eXperiment STEX developed high fidelity validation experiment ALE3D thermal explosion models. STEX medium scale experiment approximately 500-700 g explosive heated controlled rate slow 1 Cmin explosion. The experiment heavily diagnosed thermocouples embedded pressure sensor external strain gauges radar horns photo-doppler velocimetry violence high speed video. The vessel tightly sealed prevent pre-ignition leaking quench thermal explosion cases provides excellent study thermal explosion pre-ignition phenomena postignition violence. This experiment described detail previously1 however experiment matured diagnostics improve scientific questions arise. Comp-B important explosive performance fact melt-castable. The typical formulation consists approximately 60 RDX 40 TNT sometimes wax included formulation. Many studied thermal explosion Comp-B current use various applications model system melt-castable explosives. To end LLNL performed series Comp-B thermal explosion experiments reported results 2002.1 The previous STEX experiments CompB used vessels able confine explosive 1 2 kbar 100 200 MPa heating rates 1 2 3 Cmin. The results experiments demonstrated increasing confinement resulted increased violence increasing heating rate reduced violence. Because 1 2 kbar confinement pressure much larger typically found real containers e.g. storage containers study confinement necessary. To end performed two STEX experiments using kbar 50 MPa confinement vessel hermetically sealed second allowed vented experiment significantly violent hermetically sealed experiment discussed detail. The STEX design detailed previous publications1 however maturing diagnostic capabilities changes discussed briefly here. The vessel made 4130 steel inner dimensions 2 inches diameter x 8 inches tall. Diagnostics described previously internal thermocouple probe pressure gauge four strain gauges vessel exterior numerous RTD temperature probes vessel exterior radar horns measure fragment velocities explosion. New diagnostics include photo-doppler velocimetry PDV probes high speed video 150000 fps 6.67 sframe. Summary Conclusion In summary two different STEX experiments performed order understand role confinement pressure hermeticity mechanisms violence Comp-B thermal Fig. F11. DSC results Comp-B various explosions. These experiments designed complement previous STEX experiments performed 1 2 kbar. In addition goal quantify violence lightly confined unsealed experiments supply experimental data validation ALE3D explosion modeling. The sealed kbar experiment interesting demonstrated weakening vessel strength help mitigate violence. When interior pressure exceeded vessel confinement whole vessel failed vent rapid. Because material quite reached burn stage damage minimal. In designing safer casing materials vessel fail release uniformly quickly may best option minimal damage. The vented kbar surprisingly violent. Our vent designed allow pressure equilibration heating stages restrictive thermal explosion allow much mitigation violence. The vent worked designed result violent explosion. Our hypothesis material allowed fully ignite vented experiment ignited produced violent One general question remains whether venting explosives enhance mitigate violence. Our previous STEX experiments HMX-based formulations indicate vent leak little change violence explosive.1 We hypothesize explosive ignition point center charge inertial confinement helps contain reactive gases thermally insulate ignition point. As leak vent vessel wallseals little change explosion. In particular pressure rises ignition point inertial confinement prevents pressure pushing vessel walls releasing via vent. In contrast pressure rises center liquid charge quickly transferred walls vessel. The pressure rise ignition point either relieved via vent pushing vessel walls. Based logic one would surmise many liquid explosives might violent allowed small vent may mitigated via substantial vent easily destroyed vessel wall. Further work liquid explosives would provide interesting insight This research partially supported Development Program. Time Explosion Measurements An integral requirement study high quality reproducible times explosion measured well-defined controlled conditions. The One-Dimensional Time-ToExplosion Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory6 met apparatus designed The central element ODTX apparatus pair cylindrical aluminium anvils 76.2mm diameter 50.8mm high. A 12.7mm diameter hemispherical cavity machined one face anvil accept 2g spherical explosive charge similar dimensions. Recessed knife blades machined face around cavity close sealing ring provide gas tight seal containing gaseous decomposition products experiment. The anvils electrically heated means band heaters held pre-determined temperature controlled The spherical charge remotely loaded cavity face lower anvil. The upper anvil driven pre-charged pressure reservoir sealing sample cavity time 600ms. The anvil closure pressure failure confinement occur pressure within sample cavity exceeds 155MPa. Compressive Modulus curves various temperatures PBX-1 PBX-2. 3.4 Phase Transition The phase transition affects thermal decomposition explosion observably 10 11. The -HMX stable form room temperature maximum energy greatest density lowest sensitivity. When heated certain temperature -HMX transform -HMX higher sensitivity 10 11 stated previous related work. When PBX-2 heated to195C higher temperature due phase transition HMX reactions much easier occur reaction levels increased sharply9. According result Smilowitz Henson 12-14 phase transition PBX binder made estane nitro plasticizer atmospheric pressure occurred 163C much earlier highly purified crystals. They found different binders various influences phase transition temperature. Binder made estane nitro binders made TATB wax graphite reported yet. In previous work9 found binder made TATB makes phase transition HMX started 190C 195C much higher highly purified crystals. As result phase transition processes temperatures 4 PBXs cannot determined. In order remove uncertainty investigated phase transition different HMX content based PBXs XRD spectrograph results shown Fig.14. Their XRD little HMX PBX-4. By comparison 4 figures see contents HMX PBXs affect phase transition processes remarkably. The lower contents HMX higher temperature needs finish phase transition. Comparing results impact ignitions phase transition occurs obvious drop velocity threshold sharp rise impact reaction level PBX high HMX content. In contrast weight HMX PBX less 50 effect phase transition becomes insignificant. The responses PBX-1 PBX-2 change obviously heated 135C room temperature. Hooks1 1 Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos NM 87545 deformation within molecular cyclotrimethylene trinitramine RDX single crystals subjected quasistatic dynamic loading. Nanoindentation plate impact molecular dynamics simulations conducted. A review investigations results illustrates hypotheses simple slip correlate observed responses deformation RDX dependent upon orientation pressurestrain rate microstructure. Recently lineimaging velocimetry rigorously controlled crystal growth thorough characterization pursued identify control map defects solvent growth quantify effects deformation responses near Hugoniot elastic Dislocation-mediated implicated initiation mechanisms affecting detonation sensitivity explosives. However deformation molecular crystals well understood leaving many details proposed initiation mechanisms open speculation. From general understanding plasticity conventional materials deformation mechanisms known dependent upon orientation pressure strain rate initial microstructure. In order elucidate connections mechanical stimuli detonation crystal plasticity low symmetry molecular materials must characterized understood mechanistic level. Over number years assessed cyclotrimethylene trinitramine RDX looking correlations accessible slip systems several orientations. We performed quasi-static dynamic deformation investigations oriented RDX single crystals using nanoindentation plate simulations. The results revealed orientation pressure andor strain rate effects. Stochastic features near HEL wave profiles indicated possible microstructure effects therefore recently pursued line-imaging velocimetry rigorously controlled sample growth microstructure observed responses. We illustrate hypotheses simple slip account deformation molecular crystals often oversimplifications complicated effects orientation pressure andor strain rate microstructure dependencies must understanding predictive modeling. Orientation Effects At outset RDX investigations pursued approach similar used Dick seminal series studies cyclotetramethylene tetranitramine HMX.14 The three orientations shown Table 1 selected based differences ability relieve stress via known slip systems. Orientation Effects The orientation dependent HELs could correlated known quasistatic deformation deformation elementary level previously unattainable molecular materials.78 This data subsequently used constitutive material model.17 However still full understanding underlying fundamental deformation mechanisms leads significant contradictions. For example according current understanding RDX possess five independent slip systems required accommodate general strain distributions. Therefore continuum material modeling would predict incompatible strains leading cracking unrealistic strains loading. Nevertheless 100-oriented crystals wherein resolved stress known slip systems planar importance crystal indicated earlier Gross similarly confirmed materials.2119 Typically large RDX crystals used preparation samples plate impact experiments bound four large 210 habit planes enclosing c-axis. We report 100 ps time-scale compression wave speeds shocked single crystal PETN beta-HMX. The ultrafast compression rise-time high temporal resolution time-domain interferometry measurements enable characterization anisotropic sub-nanosecond dynamic response energetic materials. Wave speed measured first microns lateral propagation crystal prior onset shock induced initiation. Single crystal wave speeds reveal clear anisotropic dynamic response. For propagation direction normal 110 crystallographic plane measure predominately elastic component wave speeds. Ultrafast Shocks Measurements The ultrafast shock experimental technique used study described great detail2. We use chirped pulse amplification system CPA generate single laser pump pulse 400 J pulse energy 350 ps pulse-width 25 nm bandwidth 12 ps width rise time launch shock wave within 1 thick aluminum ablator. A shock wave propagates ablator breaks energetic material. A small fraction CPA pulse energy diverted split probe pair separated time focused collinear fashion onto propagating shock wave see Fig. 2. To identify mechanism pentaerythritol tetranitrate PETN initiated Exploding Bridgewire EBW detonators series studies performed energy tracked fireset detonator output. One outstanding questions arising studies much energy delivered post bridgewire burst contributes performance detonator. A capacitor discharge fireset developed capable limiting energy deposited system post-burst diverting pre-selected portion energy away detonator. This enabled amount energy delivered detonator controlled. The energy delivered bridgewire determined voltage current probes varied effect expansion speed unconfined bridgewires detonator functioning time determined. Exploding bridgewire EBW detonators designed 1940s Luis Alvarez1 use Manhattan Project. These detonators relatively simple construction bridgewire typically region 30m diameter 0.5 1mm length held insulating material diallylphthalate DAP common header material leads connect detonator fireset. The bridgewire embedded low density explosive fill usually PETN. There additional high density output fill may also PETN alternatively explosives Despite widely used past 70 years universally accepted initiation mechanism. The way exploding plasma interacts explosive produce detonation wave subject extensive world-wide study mechanism. It generally believed either deflagration-to-detonation DDT shock-todetonation SDT transition. Alternative theories also put forward. For example Frank suggests electric field surrounding bridgewire time burst ionizes surface explosive weak shock burst sufficient initiate explosive2 whilst Cooper Kurowski3 book Introduction Technology Explosives state EBW detonator detonated via shock transition caused bursting bridgewire. Recent work undertaken AWE45 determined shock initiation credible mechanism bridgewire initiates surrounding low density explosive fill. However remain number understanding functioning EBW detonator. The role energy deposited post bridgewire burst performance EBW detonators studied order fill one thus explodes. Densmore Mathew M. Biss Barrie E. Holman Kevin L. McNesby Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory Livermore CA 94550 Army Research Laboratory Aberdeen Proving Ground MD 21005 Abstract. Combustion nickel-aluminum NiAl aluminum-polytetrauoroethylene Al-PTFE materials studied using pressure integrated PIG chamber. The reactive material projectiles launched nominal velocity 1700 ms sealed chamber. Upon impact front cover plate projectile fragments enters chamber begins combust. There two primary reaction pathways projectile release energy solid state reaction projectile constituents oxidation reaction ambient atmosphere within chamber. Peak temperatures 3600 K NiAl 3300 K Al-PTFE reach impact. The peak quasi-static pressure reached 15-20 ms impact 28 psi NiAl 18 psi Al-PTFE. Constant volume explosion calculation CHEETAH indicate 55 total potential energy released Non-explosive energetic materials reative materials thermites investigated many applications. They interest higher mass volumetric energy densities many explosives1. In study gun launch reactive material samples supersonic velocity sealed chamber. Upon impact high shear stresses created material initiates chemical reactions. The technique similar one employed Ames2 3. Amess studies relied measurement quasi-static overpressure main metric. One rationale looking pressure structural damage primarily due blast waves. Because quasi-static pressure QSP critically dependent experimental geometry utility lies providing rel ative ranking metric performance yielding little information underlying mechanisms. Although QSP related energy output fast energy transfers working uid chamber captured. Relatively long processes like thermal conduction hot solids surrounding air underestimated. The NiAl AL-PTFE reactive materials RM supplied General Science Inc. Micronsized starting powder weighed mass RM 6832 - NiAl 2674 - AlPTFE isostatically pressed rightcircular cylinders. The length-to-diameter ratio sample approximately one. Identical molds used press sample resulting material density controlling mass sample. The higher density NiAl samples average mass 11 g lower density Al-PTFE samples average mass 6 g. Since samples pressed powders structurally strong. This resulted several samples surviving launch gun. The experimental setup shown Fig. 119. The samples sabot launched smooth bore 30 mm gun. A series break screens used measure initial sample velocity trigger diagnostic instruments. The chamber frame made rolled homogenous armour RHA steel. A front face plate sample enters chamber made 1.58 mm thick mild steel. The sample ultimately impacts rear anvil. The rear anvil made 5.08 cm thick RHA steel. The anvil able absorb multiple impacts needing replaced front face plate replaced every shot. The front wall chamber made 5 cm thick transparent polycarbonate. The projectiles complete ight path imaged using high brightness shadowgraphy system. The shadowgraphy system consisted retroreective background Cu-vapor laser light source high-speed monochrome camera. The lasers pulse width equivalent exposure time camera 20 ns. New Insights Irreversible Thermal Expansion PBX 9502 W. Lee Perry Amanda L. Duque Joseph T. Mang Edward Roemer Los Alamos National Laboratory Los Alamos New Mexico 87545 USA Abstract. TATB-based explosives known undergo irreversible thermal expansion single multiple thermal cycles. This phenomenon significant implications mechanical properties shock initiation behavior. Researchers concluded irreversibility arises due binder-crystal interactions andor damage within individual crystals. Here aim develop clearer picture damage length scale leads irreversible growth. To rapidly heated cooled PBX 9502 sample 200 C observed resulting material dye intrusion poresimmetry scanning electron microscopy small angle neutron scattering Raman spectroscopy. There clear evidence mesoscale damage length scale 1 micron less. There also indirect evidence intra-crystalline damage occur although evidence conclusive. Researchers invested considerable effort safety performance perspective mechanisms control initiation sensitivity corner-turning behavior triaminotrinitrobenzene-TATB 5 KelF 800. There general consensus mesoscale terms void size shape distribution dominates metrics. Our current understanding suggests pores voids concentrate energy shock wave number pores voids appropriate size morphology spatial distribution affect critical shock energy required initiation1 also affect corner turning Several factors formulation pressing explosive affect mesoscale morphology therefore sensitivity. The nominal parameters explosives chosen part provide balance performance. Post-manufacturing environmental factors also shown affect mesoscale morphology therefore sensitivity. Thermal expansion affects density PBX 9502 LX-17 92.5 TATB 7.5 KelF800 shown become significantly sensitive elevated temperature available evidence suggests due reduction density associated thermal expansion.3 For example run distance detonation LX-17 well supported 10 GPa shock reduced 30 mm 10 mm 75 C may prompt 200 C.3 Little directly known effect thermal expansion corner turning. Conditions lead elevated temperatures mechanical thermal damage effect thermal cycling expected service temperature range. The latter process causes phenomenon colloquially known ratchet growth occurs due irreversible thermal expansion.
